metadata.title: Nutritional Deficiencies and Diseases of Livestock

body_text.text: This chapter is divided into two parts. The first deals with principles of disease and disease control, and is an attempt to give an overview of a very complicated subject. Individual diseases are not discussed in detail, being mentioned mostly to illustrate particular points or principles.

The second part of the chapter deals with individual diseases within the categories discussed in the first part. The list is not a comprehensive one; there are many diseases within each category; those omitted are usually of less importance than those included. The individual accounts given are also not comprehensive; details of symptoms, diagnosis and treatment should be sought in pathology text-books, a list of which is given at the end of the chapter. The accounts given are primarily of the aetiology of diseases, with particular reference to basic causes and predisposing factors, either in the animal or the environment. Even with this restriction the fact remains that some diseases have a most complicated aetiology, eg many nutritional disorders. Although these have been given more space than others less complicated, the reader must look elsewhere for more comprehensive accounts.

The basis of disease control in livestock is sound management and good agricultural practice. It is true that a newly introduced disease may severely affect the bestmanaged livestock. But, without a basis of good agricultural practice, the treatment and control of disease will be difficult, and sometimes impossible.
body_text.section: Principles of Disease and Disease Control

body_text.text: Good agricultural practice also includes provision of adequate nutrition, shelter and water, a daily awareness of the health and welfare of the herd or flock, and the perception of any change in animal behaviour or appearance that may be an indication either of disease already present or of impending trouble. It means keeping the property in a good state of repair. Good fences not only mean good neighbours; they also mean an ability to segregate sick animals. Good yards allow precise and easy treatment when this is required. Good management also necessitates the keeping of adequate records of daily events so that in the event of sickness a history is available to indicate possible origins of the condition and to assist in diagnosis when outside experts are consulted.

body_text.text: Good agricultural practice implies the ability to avoid excesses, including excessive medication and excessive feeding; it implies treatment only after a satisfactory diagnosis of the cause of sickness has been made. Incorrect treatment will not only be needlessly expensive, but may aggravate the situation and be so inappropriate as to make it worse. Good management also implies good judgement and the ability to recognise when a situation is new or unfamiliar and when professional assistance is required, either for diagnosis, treatment or advice on preventive measures.
body_text.section: Principles of Disease and Disease Control

body_text.text: Disease is best considered as any departure from a normal state of health. The departure most commonly thought of is infectious disease, in which millions of micro-organisms colonise the victim's body -interrupting the food supply, poisoning through toxic excretions, and eroding and consuming vital body tissues such as the linings of intestines or lungs. Equally devastating can be diseases caused by malnutrition, poisoning, accidental injury, cancer, hereditary disease and stress. These will be considered before infectious diseases because they are in the main controlled by the good management practices that are essential before efficient control of infectious disease is possible. However, it must be noted that a disease may not fit into one category and one category only. Milk fever in cattle, for example, can be considered as due to a combination of hereditary predisposition and the stress of weather and early lactation.
body_text.section: Principles of Disease and Disease Control

body_text.text: Disease of nutritional origin may be due to deficiencies in quantity or quality of feed or both.

Deficiencies in the quantity of food available, but not necessarily the quality, lead to undernutrition. The term is a relative one, since it must be related to requirements, which are a function of the particular production objective. A nonpregnant, non-lactating animal will maintain its body-weight (and thus be adequately nourished) on an intake of feed which would lead to severe undernutrition (and thus loss of body-weight) in a lactating animal or one in late pregnancy. But a young animal growing at a rate substantially less than that of which it is genetically capable is not regarded as undernourished, in a disease sense, even though its growthrate is limited by its food intake. Undernourishment, in the sense of nutritional disease, implies an animal at risk, and this is associated, in the first instance, with loss of body-weight.

The principal undernourishment diseases are pregnancy toxaemia, or twin-lamb disease, in late-pregnant ewes and goats, and acetonaemia, or ketosis, in lactating dairy cows. Both are nutritional disorders usually affecting only those animals in a flock or herd with high nutritional requirements -ewes with twins or triplets and cows producing the largest quantity of milk. Undernourishment severe enough to lead to a well-defined and easily recognisable pathological condition, usually fatal, is primarily a result of very high nutrient requirements rather than low food intake. It is only when the food available is at a very low level, as in drought, that a high proportion of the flock or herd is affected. Even under these conditions the lactating animal can and does survive by reducing its milk production, and hence its food requirement. The pregnant animal can only reduce her requirements by aborting her foetuses, but this rarely occurs. Outbreaks of pregnancy toxaemia, affecting most pregnant ewes in the flock, are therefore common during severe drought.

Malnutrition appears when the quality of food available, but not necessarily the quantity, is inadequate to meet requirements. Whereas undernutrition is primarily an energy deficiency, malnutrition is due to food deficiencies of protein, essential amino acids or fatty acids, minerals or vitamins, or to chemical imbalances which prevent the animal utilising certain essential nutrients.

As with undernutrition, well-defined pathological conditions, often fatal, can occur primarily because the requirements for the particular nutrient are very high. Calcium and manganese deficiencies in egg-laying birds are among the best examples. Milk fever in dairy cows and goats and clinical hypocalcaemia (often referred to as milk fever) in late-pregnant ewes and goats are conditions of acute calcium deficiency arising primarily because of the animals' high requirements for calcium, to provide the large amounts of that mineral in milk and the foetal skeleton.

Absolute deficiencies in feeds and pasture are common. Australian soils, and hence pastures, are notoriously deficient in phosphorus, cobalt, copper and selenium. Cattle and horses are primarily affected by the phosphorus deficiencies in many native pastures. All ruminants are affected by cobalt-deficient pastures, mainly in South and Western Australia. In contrast to other animal species, which obtain vitamin B12 from feedstuffs of animal origin, ruminants rely on bacterial synthesis of vitamin B12 in the rumen and reticulum; cobalt is an essential constituent of this vitamin. Copper and selenium deficiencies are also fairly widespread in grazing ruminants.

Bacterial synthesis ensures adequate supplies of B-complex vitamins for ruminants and horses; deficiencies in poultry and pigs are rare because these species are largely hand-fed and synthetic vitamins are now cheap and readily incorporated into feed mixtures. In fact, it is now common practice to incorporate trace elements such as manganese and zinc, and vitamins such as vitamins A, D and B12, routinely into proprietary feed mixtures, regardless of the fact that the amounts of these constituents may already be adequate.
In contrast to humans, who must obtain their vitamin C requirements from their diet, farm animals synthesise their own requirements of vitamin C.

Animals kept outdoors in Australia synthesise their requirements of vitamin D in the presence of adequate sunlight, storing the excess of the warmer months for use when sunlight is inadequate in winter. Vitamin D deficiency symptoms are therefore most likely to be seen in pigs or poultry, housed indoors.

Hand-fed pigs and poultry receive most of their vitamin A requirements as the vitamin itself, added to the feed mixture. Grazing animals convert the abundant ß-carotene in green feed to vitamin A and can store large amounts for use when pastures are dry. Clinical signs of vitamin A deficiency therefore occur only after long periods of dietary inadequacy.

In addition to the deficiencies which arise from a frankly deficient diet, deficiencies and toxicities may occur in livestock as a result of interactions of minerals and vitamins with other constituents of the diet. High concentrations of molybdenum in pastures and feedstuffs can induce copper deficiency in livestock; very low concentrations can induce copper toxicity. High dietary concentrations of calcium or of phytic acid can induce zinc deficiency in pigs and poultry.

As a result of nutritional research, the recognition and prevention of clinical dietary deficiencies is often a very straightforward process. In fact, there is no reason why any such deficiencies should occur in hand-fed animals, particularly pigs and poultry. The situation is more difficult with grazing animals, although areas where pastures are seriously deficient in cobalt, copper, selenium and phosphorus are now well recognised. Subclinical deficiencies, leading not to obvious clinical signs, but to deleterious effects on the animal's productivity, are probably more widespread than generally recognised and more difficult to identify.
The most common causes of livestock poisoning are accidental access to farm chemicals, excessive doses of stock medicine, toxic plants in pasture and toxic feedstuffs.

Young animals and thirsty animals will often drink liquids of doubtful palatability and potential toxicity, such as sump oil and herbicides. Most potentially poisonous chemicals are labelled as such and should be stored safely. Overdosage with stock medicine should not occur if labels are carefully read.

Toxic plants in pasture are not limited to the well-known weeds such as bracken, ragwort, soursob, heliotrope and the nightshades. They include many of the grasses and legumes which constitute the sown, or improved, pastures of this country. Under appropriate seasonal weather conditions, at certain stages of growth, or when they constitute the majority of the forage available, phalaris, perennial ryegrass, annual ryegrass and white and subterranean clovers can be highly toxic. Some forage plants sown for grazing are toxic at certain stages of growth or under certain weather conditions, eg several species of Sorghum.

The known toxic constituents include cyanogenetic glycosides (sorghum and white clover), pyrrolizidine alkaloids (heliotrope, ragwort, Crotalaria spp.) oxalic acid (soursob), oestrogens (subterranean clover), goitrogens (Brassica spp.) and nitrate (grazing oats and oat forage). Tryptamine alkaloids are probably responsible for the nervous syndromes of phalaris staggers, but not for the sudden death syndrome. Lolitrem B, produced by perennial ryegrass infected with the endophyte Acremonium lolii, induces ryegrass staggers in sheep.

Cyanogenetic glycosides and nitrate are not toxic as such. The former liberate hydrocyanic acid either in the plant, when tissues are damaged (eg wilting), or in the gastro-intestinal tract of the animal which has ingested them. The latter is converted into toxic nitrite by bacterial action, either in the plant (moist hay) or in the gastro-intestinal tract.

The list of potentially toxic plants in Australian pastures is so long that is must be concluded that grazing animals are normally exposed to some risk of plant poisoning. There are several reasons why the risk of clinical toxicity is normally low.

(1) The concentration of toxin in the plant may be low. Oestrogenic substances, cyanogenetic glycosides and alkaloid neurotoxins have been detected in a wide range of species, but few are toxic. And, within a species, only certain cultivars may be toxic. Only some cultivars of white clover contain the glycoside lotaustralin; many of the cultivars of subterranean clover now available have non-toxic concentrations of oestrogens.

(2) The potentially toxic plants may have a low palatability, or constitute only a small proportion of the pasture, so that they represent only a small fraction of total food intake. There is some evidence that the higher incidence of heliotrope poisoning among British breeds of sheep is not solely due to their preponderance in affected areas; Merinos appear to find heliotrope less palatable.

(3) Animals reared in a particular environment appear to develop an ability to avoid toxic species. Catastrophic outbreaks of plant poisoning are most likely to occur when hungry animals are presented with unfamiliar, highly toxic plants; such outbreaks were formerly not uncommon on Australian stock routes, caused by, eg the high oxalic acid content of species such as soda bush (Neobassia proceriflord).

(4) Plants may be toxic only in some environments, at certain stages of growth, or under particular weather conditions. Cyanide poisoning of cattle grazing on white clover is rare in Australia, but appears to be more common in New Zealand. Sorghum spp. are highly toxic only during the early growth of the plant. Unfavourable growing conditions are associated with nitrate accumulation to toxic concentrations in many species.

It should be noted that research has tended to focus attention on clinical manifestations of plant poisoning. It is unlikely that subclinical effects, with deleterious consequences for growth and reproduction, and hence productivity, are more widespread than generally realised. Such consequences, like those of seasonal undernourishment, are difficult to measure and might easily be masked by or attributed to seasonal variation. Subclinical effects presumably also occur during the period before clinical manifestation of the disorder. Most sheep will survive at least one year's grazing on heliotrope before succumbing to chronic liver damage and toxaemic jaundice.

Poisoning of livestock can also result from the ingestion of substances which are on, rather than within, the plant ingested. Lupinosis and facial eczema are caused by liver toxins produced by fungi growing on the dead stems of lupins and the dead litter of pastures, respectively, under suitable weather conditions. Annual ryegrass toxicity requires the presence of both nematode and a Corynebacterium infection in the seed-head; the nematode is responsible for the bacterial infection. The corynetoxins produced by the bacteria can persist in dry pasture and hay.

Accidental injuries commonly seen include skin wounds, broken bones and bushfire burns. Isolated cases of injury may well be ascribed to accident but where a number of stock are similarly affected a general cause should be sought. Poorly maintained buildings and fences and derelict heaps of wire and iron commonly result in leg injuries to horses and teat cuts on dairy cattle. Small pieces of metal and wire are frequently eaten by cattle; fatal stomach perforation ('hardware disease') usually results. Design faults in yards become evident when several animals bruise themselves on the same projection in the same way during routine handling. Fighting and service injuries are often associated with one animal in the herd or flock. Fighting may be direct aggression, as when a horse develops a liking for kicking or biting cattle and sheep.

The degree of suffering and the likelihood of recovery of injured or burnt stock should be quickly and expertly assessed so that a decision can be made as to immediate destruction, salvage slaughter or treatment.

Cancerous or neoplastic growths occur when disorganised body cells multiply at a rapid rate. This happens more commonly in animals much older than those normally sold for meat or used for breeding. (Exceptions are virus-stimulated neoplasms such as leucosis in poultry, which affects younger birds and is controlled in the manner of an infectious disease.) Neoplasms are a minor cause of culling of older breeding animals; so-called 'eye cancer'is one example. Cattle with little pigmentation about the eye are susceptible to cancers in that area and these develop rapidly in response to solar radiation. Early surgical intervention will allow many of these affected animals to fulfil their breeding potential.

The occurrence of most inherited conditions has been minimised in the more common breeds of livestock by rigid culling programs. They are more likely to be in evidence in flocks or herds with a long history of injudicious inbreeding. Some hereditary conditions of importance are mannosidosis in cattle, umbilical hernia in cattle and scrotal hernia in pigs. Jaw and dental defects are seen in all breeds of animal and are commonly associated with particular breeding combinations. Where a hereditary disease is shown to be present it is unwise to continue breeding from that line.

Stress is often a factor contributing to the development of other diseases. Stress may be physical or psychological. Common physical stresses are those associated with weather, particularly extremes of heat and cold, with undernourishment, and with sustained or excessive muscular exertion. Psychological stresses are associated with overcrowding, handling and unfamiliar environments. The latter may be the shearing shed, the saleyard, a transport vehicle or even a new paddock.

Overcrowding is an important contributing cause of increased infectious disease incidence, and of injuries due to fighting. However, with experience and attention to detail, animals and birds can be kept under intensive conditions with advantages to health, production and breeding ability. This is due to the ability to monitor health more closely, to maintain comfortable temperature ranges and to control distribution of food.

Protection may be needed to avoid either extreme heat or extreme cold. Heat stress is considerably reduced by providing shade and ready access to water. Cold stress is largely due to the additional chilling effect of winds and rain, over and above the effect of temperature per se. Domestic animals can survive in the coldest parts of Australia provided there are adequate windbreaks.

Exhaustion by over-exercise is easily understood. The nutritional exhaustion seen in dairy cattle after a prolonged lactation followed immediately by calving, without a dry period, is perhaps less appreciated, as is the strain placed on twin-pregnant ewes through lack of feed. The effect of exhaustion from either overwork or overproduction is greatly increased when there is lack of adequate food and/or cold, wet conditions.

Infectious diseases are those caused by living agents. These include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, helminths and arthropods. The majority, including many of the helminths (parasitic worms) and some of the arthropods (mainly mites), are of microscopic size. The infected animal is often referred to as the host animal.

Some causal agents of infectious disease are adapted to living entirely within the animal body, leaving it only to be passed to other host animals by more or less direct means. Others may be able to live away from the host for some, or even all, of their life. Infectious agents cause disease in part by destroying the host's tissues, causing continual strain on the body's ability to repair and replace tissue. They may excrete toxins that disrupt normal body function. Their presence may constitute a drain on the body's energy supplies. They are normally able to reproduce very rapidly. The host, however, has specialised tissues and cells which allow the body to recognise materials as foreign to itself and to eliminate or neutralise them. Once the host animal has experienced a disease it may also increase its resistance to further infections through the development of immunity. For these reasons many animals may harbour potential disease-causing living agents yet not show any indication of disease.

Most micro-organisms found in the body are situated in the intestinal tract, where they provide valuable services: producing vitamins for the host, reducing the numbers of harmful bacteria, and occasionally detoxifying poisons before they can be absorbed into the body. Ruminant animals and horses rely on such micro-organisms to digest the cellulose in their diet.

The degree of infectivity of contagious diseases varies considerably. Some will readily spread among animals of the same herd or flock by direct contact. Others will spread only after passing part of their life in another species, eg malaria in mosquitoes. Many have little ability to invade the body and may only infect animals with a diminished resistance.

Chances of infection are increased when huge numbers of organisms are present in the environment and when the animal is forced to combat disproportionately large numbers of these, eg when feed and drinking water are contaminated.

Bacteria are common causes of enteritis, pneumonia, arthritis, abscesses, mastitis and infection of wounds. They commonly contaminate the environment, and many disease-producing bacteria are capable of multiplying in moist, shaded soil, manure and in dirty equipment, including dirty, badly maintained sheep dips. Animals may become infected from such an environment through contamination of accidental or surgical (dog castration) wounds or through feed and water contamination. It is usually not possible to remove every source of contamination but efforts made to clean and sterilise syringes and surgical equipment, to castrate animals under clean conditions, and to keep shearing sheds and dips clear of contamination, will dramatically reduce the number of abscesses and arthritic joints seen on the property. Similarly, efforts to prevent contamination of food and water, especially by dung, will be of great benefit in reducing the likelihood of bacterial enteritis, and clean pastures and yards will reduce the incidence of parasitic diseases, such as coccidiosis and helminth worms.

Bacterial numbers are best reduced by removing the dirt and organic matter in which they survive. The use of disinfectants may be warranted if instruments or premises are clean, but not before, since disinfectants are rapidly destroyed in the presence of organic matter such as rotting hair and manure and virulent organisms may actually remain protected within a wall of dirt and inactivated disinfectant. Dirt can also provide a barrier against sterilising heat and hence any equipment sterilised by boiling, such as syringes and castration knives, should be well cleaned beforehand.

Some equipment cannot be boiled, and use of chemical disinfectant may be necessary. With syringes, all traces of the chemical should be removed with boiled water to prevent damage to the vaccine or drug used, or irritation to the animal.
Bacteria that do not form resistant spores are generally destroyed within days of dry conditions and sunshine. For this reason the open paddock is not a prime source of new infections.

Spore-forming bacteria develop tough capsules that are virtually impervious to disinfectants and can resist some degree of boiling. Cleanliness can reduce the number present in the environment but in itself is not sufficient for control. Diseases caused by spore-forming bacteria of importance in Australia are anthrax (fortunately restricted to a few regions) and several diseases produced by clostridial bacteria. All can be prevented by vaccination.

Clostridial diseases of importance are Clostridium tetani (causing tetanus), Cl. botulinum (botulism), Cl. chauvoei (blackleg), Cl. septicum (braxy), Cl. novyi (black disease) and Cl perfringens type D (enterotoxaemia or pulpy kidney). All can be present in the healthy animal and all under certain circumstances will produce powerful toxins. These can produce either tissue death and gangrene or severe nervous disorders. All clostridial diseases are fatal in most farm situations. In addition to the pure infections, mixed infections may give rise to gangrene of wounds.

Clostridial vaccines are 'killed'vaccines. These contain dead portions of the diseaseproducing organisms which cause immunity to be developed against living bacteria of the same species. To be effective, however, a series of killed vaccine injections is required. Most formulations require two injections approximately four to six weeks apart followed by a third injection 12 months to two years later; it is essential to follow the manufacturer's instructions. There is, in all cases, a 10-to 14-day delay before animals are protected. Tetanus is a likely disease of sheep and horses in all parts of Australia. Vaccination of sheep against enterotoxaemia is generally advisable. Requirements for other clostridial vaccines and for other species are determined by local conditions.

Other bacterial diseases of substantial economic significance include foot abscess and posthitis in sheep and mastitis in cattle. Mastitis is caused by several organisms, of which the streptococci are readily controlled by antibiotic therapy whereas staphylococci are not. Subclinical mastitis is probably responsible for a major part of the total loss in milk production.

Animals may be given immediate temporary immunisation against many microorganisms by injecting into them serum from an immune animal. This procedure is frequently used on valuable individual animals but it is usually too expensive to use in a flock. Anticipation of needs and early preventive vaccination, where effective, are to be preferred.

When bacterial infection does occur it is well not to proceed without professional help unless the diagnosis is certain and the method of treatment understood. Antibiotics may not always be the most suitable treatment and with some infections such as salmonellosis they can prolong the period of the disease. Moreover, it is important to use the correct antibiotic for each type of bacteria; too many look for 'something stronger' when the first haphazard choice is found to be unsatisfactory.

Most of the serious viral diseases of animals do not occur in Australia. Strict quarantine regulations are designed to continue to keep Australia free of such diseases as bluetongue in sheep, rinderpest in cattle, swine fever in pigs, Newcastle disease in poultry and the multi-host foot-and-mouth disease and rabies. (See Chapter 34.)

The viral disease most likely to be encountered is scabby mouth in sheep. Scabby mouth, a descriptive term of greater vividness than the more scientific contagious ecthyma, is typical of virus diseases in that it does not respond to any antibiotic and a natural attack will produce a lasting immunity. Scabby mouth vaccine contains the fully virulent organism, and the aim of vaccination is to cause an infection in a place where it is difficult for the virus to become established (the inside of the thigh). Animals so vaccinated can readily transmit the natural infection to other animals and contaminate the property with infective viral particles since, like many viruses, scabby mouth is much more resistant to sunlight and desiccation than bacteria. Scabby-mouth vaccination is recommended only for sheep at obvious risk. Vaccination on a property free of the disease means introducing a new disease for no purpose.

Australian livestock are little troubled by fungal diseases, the exception being ringworm in cattle and horses. Superficial fungal infections respond well to treatment with fungicides. However, when antibiotics are used excessively, so many bacteria may be removed from a site that their places are taken by antibiotic-resistant fungi. In this way incurable fungal pneumonia and enteritis have occurred as a direct result of antibiotic treatment.
Other cases of fungal pneumonia and abortion have been seen, associated with severe contamination of available feed with fungal spores.

These micro-organisms differ from bacteria and fungi in that they are microscopic unicellular members of the animal kingdom. Most protozoa are free-living in soil or water but few are wholly parasitic on animal hosts. The most likely to be encountered in Australia are coccidial infections of lambs, goats, cattle and poultry. Coccidia of one species of animal do not cause disease in other species but nevertheless their appearance and life cycles are very similar. In northern parts of Australia a group of protozoan blood parasites causing tick fever are of major economic importance.

Coccidia are intestinal parasites that cause considerable erosion and damage to the mucosal lining, with resultant blood-stained diarrhoea. The infective stage is passed in faeces and survival is enhanced by moist, cool conditions. Other animals are infected by eating contaminated feed. An outbreak of disease is most likely when animals are intensively hand-fed but is greatly diminished if faecal contamination of feed and water is prevented. Infected animals respond well to appropriate medicinal treatment.

These include the flat segmented tapeworms that can reach a length of several metres, the flat leaf-like fluke of which only liver fluke and stomach fluke (paramphistomes) occur in Australia, and a variety of nematodes or roundworms, affecting mainly the lungs and intestines.

Tapeworms have two very dissimilar stages in their life cycle: the unmistakable tapeworm found in the final host and a cystic stage present in the intermediate host. Two tapeworms of considerable importance in Australia are Echinococcus granulosus and Taenia ovis. Both infect dogs, but in the intermediate cystic form the first is the cause of hydatid disease in sheep, cattle and man and the second the cause of sheep measles. Hydatid disease is of economic importance because of the rejection of affected livers at abattoirs while sheep measles forms cysts throughout the whole carcass and is a major reason for abattoir rejection. Both types of cyst develop into tapeworms when eaten by dogs. At maturity the worms produce eggs that are passed in the faeces and eventually contaminate the dog's coat, pasture and market-garden produce. The hydatid egg may contaminate hands and household food and so lead to human hydatid disease -a serious, often fatal, condition. Because of risk of hydatid disease it is recommended that dogs are not fed any liver or lungs. (Cooking to destroy cysts is often carried out inadequately.) Any mutton fed to dogs should be frozen for a week to destroy measle cysts. Efficient worm treatments for dogs are now available but these must be supported by efforts to prevent reinfection.

Liver fluke {Fasciola hepatica) is a common and serious parasite of sheep and cattle in high-rainfall areas, on irrigated pasture and on pasture adjoining swamps. Like the tapeworm this fluke is a two-host parasite, developing into a flat leafshaped worm in the bile ducts of sheep, cattle and even pigs at the adult stage. In passing from egg to adulthood it spends an immature period as a parasite of Lymnaea tomentosa, a species of water snail. If this snail is present (expert identification is readily available) then it is possible that sheep, and to a lesser extent cattle, will become fluke-infested.

Fluke damage to the final host may be due to massive necrosis of the liver when large numbers of immature fluke are consumed during grazing and penetrate that organ. Lesser penetration may cause sufficient damage to permit development of the clostridial bacterium causing black disease (see below). Chronic fluke disease (fasciolosis) occurs with lower infestations and is augmented by nutritional stress and the gradual scarring of the liver caused by the presence of adult worms.

Control of fluke is dependent on reducing numbers to the minimum by three means. Firstly, stock in affected areas should be drenched in early summer to remove immature flukes before liver damage can be caused and before they are mature enough to lay eggs; additional drenches may be required according to local conditions. Secondly, snails should be controlled by copper treatment or draining of their swampy habitats, the action taken depending on practicability and with due consideration of the fact that copper salts are not only highly toxic to snails but also to fish, and may accumulate in pasture. Thirdly, areas of swamp -the prime snail habitat and most dangerous place for infection -should be fenced off from sheep and used only by the more resistant cattle.

Usually referred to simply as 'worms', parasitic nematodes cause one of the most important animal health problems of Australian livestock and treatment against worms is a routine task for the majority of stockowners. Although nematodes are extremely common there is much variation in significance from district to district, year to year and month to month.

Over 60 genera (and many more species) of parasitic nematodes affect Australian livestock. Almost all are capable of completing their life cycle in a single host. Infection is usually spread among animals by eggs passed in the faeces; from these develop infective larval worms which are capable of 'swimming' in the thin film of moisture on blades of wet grass. As a result, they can be consumed during grazing. Under intensive conditions, and heavy contamination, infection may be from faecal soiling of feedstuffs. All infective larvae need some environmental moisture, either from rain or dew, to survive, but the needs vary from species to species.

Worms are not usually a problem in grazing animals in districts with less than 400 mm rainfall. The problem increases with rainfall or on irrigated pasture. Worms are also sensitive to temperature; optimal ranges vary from species to species. In ruminant animals these differing moisture and temperature needs result in certain worms such as the barber's pole worm {Haemonchus spp.) being more common where summer rainfall predominates and others, such as trichostrongyles, being a problem after winter rainfall.

The typical nematode parasitic stages are several immature larval stages that may be spent in body tissues. Considerable damage can be done to these tissues before the adult worm commences feeding and egg-laying in the lumen of the intestinal tract. Examples of larval damage are the stomach injury caused in ruminants by Ostertagia larvae and the injury to arterial walls caused in horses by the larvae of strongyle worms.

Adult worms may cause sickness by bloodsucking (eg Haemonchus spp.) and by severely damaging the stomach and intestines during feeding. A few species parasitise and damage other organs such as lungs or kidneys. With the exception of ascarids (popularly known as roundworms), found in horses and pigs, which may reach several centimetres in length, most adult nematodes are 2 to 20 mm long and may be quite difficult to see.

Worms can rarely be eliminated from a property so control is directed to reducing environmental contamination and to treating animals before worm burdens have affected health. Before developing a drenching program for a property it is wise to discuss the matter with a veterinary surgeon or government officers who can suggest methods appropriate to the livestock, the property and the district. Some general principles should, however, be considered.

Worms should be attacked in the animal with oral anthelmintic drenches which are known to be effective against the worms present on the property. During the 1980s it has become common practice to test for drench resistance on properties, to determine which chemicals should be used. Purchased sheep can introduce resistant worms on to a property, and such sheep should be drenched on arrival. The treatment should be effective against immature worms. Finally a check should be made to ensure that special restrictions on use do not apply. Some treatments are not suitable for certain classes of animal (eg young or pregnant) or may cause residues in feedstuffs, eg dairy products. All this information will be on the label.

The timing of drenching should be such as to achieve economical control and especially to interrupt pasture contamination. In most circumstances this can be achieved by four or five strategic drenches yearly -less in low-rainfall areas, more under wet or irrigation conditions or in some forms of intensive farming. The most important strategic drench is at the beginning of the summer dry period in southern Australia -usually in November or December. A second drench is given during the summer (February). Where drenching is for sickness, rather than control, treatment should be immediate, and repeated as indicated.

Young animals are more susceptible than older ones and many methods have been suggested for reducing their exposure. Pregnant animals may be treated so that egg contamination of the pasture and infection of their offspring is reduced.

Pastures are frequently rotationally grazed and spelled on the grounds that infective larvae will die within several weeks. Recent investigation, however, has shown that pasture has to be spelled for much longer than the month previously considered satisfactory and that certain eggs such as those of Ostertagia spp. will lie dormant on the pasture under dry conditions for many months, only to hatch when rainfall occurs. For this reason understanding of the particular local worm problem is required before recommendations can be made.

Alternate grazing by different species of animals has been practised on the grounds that one will harvest the other's infective larvae and these will not reach adulthood in the strange host. Some worms, however, are common to more than one species and this is particularly so with ruminants.

Under intensive conditions, cleaning of the premises may be indicated and certainly faecal contamination of feed and water must be strenuously avoided, not only to reduce worm buildup, but to prevent coccidial, bacterial and other types of disease.

Arthropod parasites are characterised by a hard external surface and by jointed legs. Insects are arthropods, as are spiders. Included among arthropod parasites are two relatives of spiders: ticks and mites. There are also three groups of insect: flies, fleas and lice. Most arthropod parasites are ectoparasites and feed either on skin and skin debris or by bloodsucking. Exceptions are mites, which make microscopic burrows in the skin, and the parasitic larvae of some flies, which penetrate quite deeply into the body. Harmful effects may be produced for one or more of the following reasons. Skin irritation. Biting flies, such as the stable fly, will cause distress through pain whereas the effect of sheep-biting lice (body lice), sandflies, mosquitoes and others is more subtle. In some cases the host may become allergic to the parasite. The harmful results of what appears to be minor irritation can be considerable. Animals may be prevented from grazing, handling of animals is made difficult, and constant scratching may injure hide, hair or wool. Skin damage may be seen where large, bloodsucking parasites pierce the skin in order to feed. Not only is the immediate health of the animal affected, but hide damage by cattle tick and demodectic mange can be particularly severe and will greatly affect the value of the hide. Damage to deeper tissues is mainly due to the feeding habits of parasitic fly larvae. In Australia, sheep are most commonly and most severely affected. Anaemia. Blood loss can be severe where very high parasite populations occur. Anaemia and death associated with severe tick or lice infestations of cattle are not uncommon. Disease transmission. Arthropods may, in addition to causing obvious physical damage, spread some very serious diseases. Certain viruses, bacteria and protozoa may be taken up by a bloodsucking parasite, survive and multiply within the parasite and later infect healthy animals at subsequent feedings. The most serious arthropodtransmitted disease in Australia is tick fever of cattle, which is confined to the northern parts of the continent.

Parasitism may involve the whole life cycle, as with lice and mange mites, where all stages soon die if removed from the animal. On the other hand it may involve only one part of the cycle; an example is the larval stage of the sheep blowfly, Lucilia cuprina. Other parasitic associations may be minimal, as with mosquitoes, bush flies etc. The closer the parasitic relationship and the more specific the dependency on a single animal species, the greater is the chance that flock or herd treatment will be effective; no reservoir of infection will remain on the property.

Animal parasiticide preparations are safe and effective if used in the proper manner. However, if concentrations greater than recommended are used, stock poisoning can occur; improper use is also a hazard to the operator. Many preparations are absorbed rapidly through the skin; it is not necessary for them to be inhaled or ingested.

Some chemical ingredients will take weeks or even years to be eliminated from the body of a treated animal. This can render meat and milk products unfit for human consumption. For this reason some cannot be used on food-producing animals; others may not be used on milking cows and goats. There may also be withholding periods -minimum times between treatment of an animal and its slaughter for human consumption.

The most important diseases of nutritional origin are probably the mineral deficiency diseases, particularly cobalt, copper and selenium deficiencies, which affect all classes of ruminant grazing on pastures deficient in these elements. Other major nutritional disorders include clinical hypocalcaemia (milk fever) and pregnancy toxaemia (twinlamb disease), which affect ewes in late pregnancy, and their counterparts, milk fever and acetonaemia (ketosis), which affect primarily dairy cattle in early lactation. Hypomagnesaemia (grass tetany) occurs in lactating cows and rarely in sheep; bloat is a major problem in cattle.

body_text.text: Pasture plants contain no vitamin B12. Micro-organisms in the rumen synthesise this vitamin, which contains 4 per cent cobalt, for their own use; the grazing ruminant obtains its supply from this source. If the concentration of cobalt in pasture is low, the micro-organisms fail to thrive, digestion in the rumen and reticulum slows down and food intake declines to low levels. Animals fail to grow or may even lose bodyweight, become emaciated and die of starvation. Cobalt-deficient pastures occur particularly in Western Australia and South Australia, and in localised areas in other States. The clinical diseases were originally called wasting disease in cattle and coast disease in sheep.

Subclinical disease is difficult to diagnose since it may be indistinguishable from seasonal undernourishment. Lambs are most affected, and their failure to thrive may be wrongly attributed to other causes. It is important to correct cobalt deficiency in lambs and calves in spring when energy and protein are not limiting for growth.
Pastures over large areas of Western and South Australia are also copper-deficient.

Other pastures, particularly in other States, may apparently contain sufficient copper, yet deficiency symptoms which respond to copper administration appear in animals grazing these pastures. Copper metabolism in the animal is markedly affected by its intake of other minerals, particularly iron, molybdenum and sulfate. A high dietary concentration of molybdenum inhibits the retention of copper and can therefore induce copper deficiency in an animal with an otherwise adequate copper intake. The use of fertilisers containing molybdenum, to promote the growth of clovers in pasture, or the use of lime to promote molybdenum uptake from acid soils, with the same objective, may create an imbalance between the concentrations of copper and molybdenum in the pasture, leading to copper deficiency in the animal.

Since the effect of molybdenum is, in turn, dependent of the sulfate content of the diet, it is perhaps not surprising that copper deficiency symptoms vary from soil to soil and pasture to pasture in a sometimes unpredictable manner. The loss of crimp and characteristic 'steely wool', which result from defective keratinisation, may be the only clinical manifestation of copper deficiency in sheep on copperdeficient soils in South Australia. Enzootic ataxia, a nervous disorder characterised by inco-ordination of movement, is associated with lesions of the spinal cord. Occurring particularly in Western Australia, it affects lambs and kids; calves are not affected. Anaemia, scouring and post-parturient haemoglobinuria occur in cattle. The first occurs in all species, but the other two appear to be confined to cattle. One of the most striking symptoms, occurring only in cattle, is myocardial atrophy with replacement fibrosis. The development of this condition on copper-deficient soils in Western Australia leads eventually to cardiac failure and the sudden death ('falling disease') of cattle, while sheep on the same pasture show no such symptoms.

In some instances, copper poisoning occurs in sheep on pastures which do not contain excessive concentrations of copper. A low dietary molybdenum intake promotes copper retention, and this may prove toxic to the sheep. Sheep may be found dead, or alive and weak and seen to be passing red-brown coloured urine. Subterranean clover takes up very little molybdenum in warm conditions; germination in late summer or early autumn may lead to a clover-dominant pasture with an adequate but not excessive content of copper and a very low molybdenum content, predisposing sheep to copper poisoning.

Many Australian soils and pastures have been found to contain very low concentrations of selenium. This mineral is required by animals for enzymes involved in muscle and heart function, detoxification processes, and the immune system. The main deficiency disorder is white muscle disease, or muscular dystrophy, and is seen mainly in young lambs, and occasionally in calves. It is more common in spring in high-rainfall areas on sown pastures, containing clover, which have been well-fertilised with superphosphate. Muscle problems also occur in lambs on dry pastures in summer and autumn, and these can be due to selenium and vitamin E deficiency. Vitamin E deficiency is often seen in weaner lambs fed grain during dry autumn periods. Selenium supplementation has increased the body and wool growth of Merino lambs less than 15 months of age in the low-selenium areas.
Phosphorus deficiency occurs in cattle and horses in Queensland ('peg-leg'), and in cattle in other States, but there is no evidence that it ever occurs in sheep.

Pastures containing low concentrations of phosphorus are usually deficient in energy and protein, so that energy deficiency is the first limiting nutritional factor, and effectively masks the incipient phosphorus deficiency in most instances. This is shown by the fact that phosphorus deficiency is seen in cattle only when energy is not limiting, ie when the animals are gaining weight. The reasons why sheep do not become phosphorus-deficient on pastures on which cattle develop clinical deficiency signs are not clear. The several explanations so far advanced are not convincing. The ability of sheep to graze more selectively is clearly one important reason.

It is important to note that the deleterious effects of mineral deficiencies on the productivity of grazing animals are not confined to those areas where obvious, recognisable symptoms occur. One of the first effects of most mineral deficiencies is some degree of inappetence in affected animals. In mild deficiency this may be the only symptom, one which is difficult to detect and impossible to measure. The result may be a lowering of overall productivity of the flock or herd, evidenced by reduced growth-rates, a lowered reproduction rate and, in sheep, reduced woolgrowth, effects which are not specific to the mineral deficiency concerned, but which result from the reduced energy and protein intakes. This invisible production loss is nevertheless of considerable economic importance. It is 'invisible' because the level of productivity obtained will tend to be regarded as 'normal' for the district or area. Better diagnostic criteria are gradually revealing these areas of subclinical deficiency. Or they are being identified through field experiments showing increased animal productivity following the administration of mineral supplements.

The mineral concentrations in soils in mineral-deficient areas are not necessarily low. The uptake of cobalt and copper, by pasture plants, from alkaline soils is poor; molybdenum uptake is lower on acid soils; superphosphate application reduces selenium uptake. Correcting pasture deficiencies by applying fertilisers containing the minerals may thus be the least satisfactory method of correcting the deficiency in the grazing animal, and in some areas where fertilisers are not normally used will be impractical. The exception is the application to acid soils of superphosphate containing added copper; the copper concentration in pasture will be increased and pasture growth may be stimulated. Otherwise, the administration of cobalt, copper, selenium and phosphorus to the grazing animal will give better results.

Pregnancy toxaemia affects ewes, primarily those carrying twins or more, in the last month of pregnancy. Undernourishment is an essential prerequisite. This may be progressive, when feed supplies deteriorate in quality and/ or quantity as pregnancy progresses, or sudden in onset, when ewes in late pregnancy are temporarily deprived of feed for periods as short as 24 hours. In the latter case, ewes which are already undernourished will be the first affected. Other predisposing factors, all involving progressive or sudden undernourishment, include diseases such as foot rot or foot abscess, prolonged bad weather, and mustering and yarding. If undernourishment is severe, as in drought, ewes with single lambs may also be affected and flock losses may be heavy.

If undernutrition is the principal factor, as in any sustained dry period, affected ewes will show progressive depression of consciousness culminating in coma and death. Since the symptoms are the result of a vain effort by the animal to adjust its metabolism in response to an acute tissue-glucose deficiency, they are similar to the symptoms of diabetic coma in humans which is also the result of an acute tissue insufficiency of glucose, resulting not from a lack of glucose per se, as in the ewe, but from a lack of the hormone insulin, which is necessary for tissueglucose utilisation. Correcting the glucose insufficiency, by injecting glucose or by administering glycerine orally, is ineffective after loss of consciousness, because other metabolic dysfunctions, which include acidosis, uraemia, dehydration, failure of kidney function and hypokalaemia, remain.

There is, however, another condition, also defined as pregnancy toxaemia. This occurs in ewes, well nourished or not severely undernourished, subjected to a combination of stress and food deprivation. The commonest stress is that of unfamiliar environments (eg transport, saleyards, further transport and then unfamiliar paddocks). If the ewes are deprived of food during the period of stress, a large number may show clinical signs of depression of consciousness, usually after the period of stress is apparently over. Acidosis and its associated metabolic dysfunctions often do not occur; the symptoms are not those of the syndrome described above, and ewes with single lambs can be affected. Early administration of glycerine or electrolyte-replacer solutions containing glucose can induce dramatic recoveries in a high percentage of affected animals.
Occasional outbreaks of this second syndrome have been recorded in pregnant cows after being transported long distances on agistment.

Finally, it should be noted that very fat pregnant ewes are curiously susceptible in late pregnancy to the stress of an unfamiliar environment. Their food intake is depressed or they refuse to eat; those with twins are most affected. Some become seriously undernourished and develop the first syndrome described above, often several days or up to two weeks after the move to the unfamiliar environment. This may explain the occasional outbreaks of pregnancy toxaemia in fat ewes with apparently ample pasture feed; the stress precipitating the inappetence may have occurred some time before the outbreak.

Deaths of pregnant beef cows in late summer are now fairly common in areas of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia which have adopted early-autumn calving. These cows are exposed to severe undernourishment in late pregnancy in dry summers, and the clinical condition which may develop appears to be akin to pregnancy toxaemia caused in sheep by sustained undernourishment.

Clinical hypocalcaemia in ewes in late pregnancy may be confused with pregnancy toxaemia. Isolated cases can occur after yarding, crutching, or shearing in late pregnancy. There is usually an interruption of feeding, eg through being held in yards overnight. Some of the largest outbreaks have, however, occurred in latepregnant ewes isolated from their normal pasture by floods or subjected to one or two days of heavy rain in late pregnancy. Ewes with single foetuses appear to be most affected; in some situations associated with yarding and crutching, several ewes with single foetuses may show the symptoms of hypocalcaemia and one or two with twins will develop pregnancy toxaemia. Accurate diagnosis, which requires experience, is essential.

Milk fever in dairy cows usually occurs within a few days of calving. The basic cause is the sudden additional demand for calcium after calving, to supply the relatively high concentration of this mineral in milk. The resulting hypocalcaemia is due to a failure to absorb sufficient calcium from the intestine and to mobilise calcium from bone. This is despite all the hormonal controls of calcium metabolism responding normally. Milk fever usually does not affect cows before their fourth lactation (five-year-olds). As cows grow older they are less able to mobilise calcium from their bone reserves and therefore become more prone to milk fever.

Very fat and very thin cows are most susceptible to milk fever, and the management of older cows in the herd is the key to the prevention of this disorder. The most common preventive method in Australia is to feed cows mainly hay and very little lush pasture during the two weeks before calving. After calving the calcium intake should be increased by feeding the cow on good pasture, and providing supplements containing additional calcium when pasture is limiting. The concentrate supplements should provide at least an additional 50 g calcium per day -adding 125 g limestone provides 50 g calcium.

Low magnesium intake, and phosphorus deficiency, can make cows more susceptible to milk fever. Where cows have low blood magnesium concentrations, magnesium oxide should be added to the hay at the rate of 60 g per cow per day.
Feeding excessive calcium to pregnant cows can make them more prone to milk fever; lucerne and clover hays, or diets intended for lactating cows, should not be fed to cows before calving.

Acetonaemia is a disease of lactating dairy cows characterised by nervous signs, loss of body weight, reduced milk yield, and ketone bodies in the urine and milk. Many of the biochemical changes are similar to those in other ketotic conditions of ruminants, including pregnancy toxaemia of sheep, cows and goats. The disease is characterised by a low blood-glucose concentration and an accumulation of ketone bodies in body fluids. There is also an increase in plasma free fatty acids and liver fat, and a decrease in liver glycogen and glucose content. These changes are associated with an inadequate supply of nutrients for the normal carbohydrate and fat metabolism associated with high milk production usually seen in early lactation. Maximum milk yield usually occurs during the third week of lactation, but maximum food intake by the cow may not be achieved until the seventh week after parturition. Cows of any age, including heifers, may be affected. The most successful control of the problem is by attention to feeding and management to ensure that cows have an adequate energy intake after calving.

Grass tetany occurs in lactating cows in the southern States, usually between May and September. The overall incidence in beef cattle may reach 2 per cent in socalled 'tetany-prone' areas. Most cases occur in the first few weeks after calving. Affected animals may be found dead, with evidence that they had been thrashing around shown by the marks on the ground around the cow. Mildly affected animals may show excitement and increased nervousness.

Various types of the disorder are recognised on farms. The most common is where only cows older than six years are affected. These cows are usually very fat, and losses occur when they have inadequate pasture in autumn and winter after calving. Supplementation with hay with added magnesium oxide prevents hypomagnesaemia and grass tetany.

In other herds, younger cows may be affected. Cows grazing lush pastures have difficulty absorbing sufficient calcium, and hypocalcaemia in addition to hypomagnesaemia precipitates grass tetany. Feeding hay to cows enables them to maintain blood-calcium levels. Cows on phosphorus-deficient pastures have difficulty in maintaining blood-calcium concentrations.

Pastures top dressed with potash and nitrogen are often associated with outbreaks of grass tetany. Potassium and ammonia inhibit magnesium absorption from the rumen. Pastures low in sodium are also tetany-prone, and salt licks or blocks should be provided for herds grazing these pastures.

Sheep are less susceptible to grass tetany than cattle. Outbreaks occur where lactating ewes are grazing very short green pastures in the autumn. It is important to avoid management procedures which stop lactating ewes or cows from grazing. Shelter and supplementary feed should be provided to animals most at risk of grass tetany.

Bloat is simply retention of gas in the reticulo-rumen. The average cow produces, and eliminates, 200 to 600 L of carbon dioxide and methane each day. In bloat, the normal balance between production of these gases by micro-organisms and their elimination by belching is disturbed; the inflated reticulo-rumen interferes with normal respiration; death can occur within an hour.

Bloat occurs in animals grazing young, lush pasture, particularly with a high legume content. Lucerne and clover are most likely to be involved. A stable proteinaceous foam forms in the rumen and inhibits the escape of gas from the rumen contents and hence its likelihood of escaping from the rumen via the oesophagus. The factors involved in foam formation are complex and are still not clearly understood.
Cattle are primarily affected, but bloat may occur in sheep. There is a great variation in susceptibility between animals of the same breed.

Prevention by drenching the animals regularly with water-soluble detergents during the susceptible period is cheap and effective. Flank application of anti-foaming agents is less effective since it relies on each animal licking its own or another's flanks. Spraying pastures daily with anti-foaming agents is clearly likely to be most successful if cows are being strip-grazed.

So-called feedlot bloat occurs in cattle being fed on diets containing mostly concentrates, although feed mixtures containing lucerne hay are believed to be particularly likely to cause the disturbance. Feedlot bloat develops slowly, over several weeks, and tends to become chronic. The foam has properties quite different from those of pasture-bloat foam; pluronics are not as effective, but anti-foaming agents or detergents are still the best preventives.

Pastures dominated by subterranean clover cultivars with a high content of oestrogenic substances can be associated with grossly impaired reproduction in grazing sheep. Dystocia in ewes, high perinatal lamb losses, and infertility associated with pathological changes (cystic endometria) in the genital tract may reduce lambmarking percentages to insignificant levels. The impairment of reproduction is permanent.

The oestrogenic substances are principally the isoflavones genistein, formononetin, biochanin A and diadzein. They occur in other clovers; permanent infertility has been reported in ewes grazing on red-clover pastures.

The subterranean-clover cultivars Dwalganup, Yarloop and Dinninup have the highest oestrogenic potencies; Geraldton has a somewhat lower toxicity. The much higher incidence of reproductive disturbances in Western Australia than in the eastern States is explained by the fact that the first two of these cultivars predominate in Western Australian pastures. New cultivars mostly have low oestrogenic potencies (see subterranean clover in Chapter 11).
Clover dominance is not an essential prerequisite for pasture toxicity, which also varies from property to property for reasons which are not completely understood.

This nervous disorder in sheep can be acute or chronic. The acute form appears very soon after sheep begin grazing Phalaris aquatica pastures and is seen as excitement, tremors and uncoordinated movements which may appear particularly when the sheep are driven. The chronic nervous syndrome develops over a longer period than the acute nervous syndrome. The neurological signs of the chronic syndrome persist after animals are removed from the pasture; those of the acute syndrome usually disappear rapidly and completely, but may re-appear in some sheep if they are driven and stressed. Phalaris aquatica contains tryptamine alkaloids which are thought to be responsible for the nervous syndromes. An adequate intake of cobalt is required to prevent the alkaloids causing the nervous disorder. This effect of cobalt is not mediated through Vitamin B12. The concentration of cobalt in the rumen is important for prevention of the disorder, and more than one cobalt pellet may be required to be given to sheep to prevent phalaris staggers.
There is also a sudden death syndrome associated with grazing phalaris pastures. This sudden death syndrome is caused by cardiac arrest thought to be due to a factor like cyanide in the plant.

This disease in sheep is the result of an increased sensitivity of exposed skin to sunlight, brought about by a photosensitising agent, phylloerythrin. This is a breakdown product of the chlorophyll contained in ingested pasture, which accumulates in the blood only when the liver is damaged by the toxin, sporidesmin, produced by a fungus, Pithomyces chartarum. The fungus grows on dead plant material in late summer or autumn pasture under favourable weather conditions of ample moisture and high minimum temperatures.
There is no effective treatment after the face lesions have appeared. Prevention involves reducing or preventing the intake of toxic pasture.

This disease is caused by a toxin lolitrem B which is produced in perennial ryegrass plants infected with Acremonium lolii, an endophyte fungus. There are cultivars of ryegrass which have no endophyte fungus. The fungus is transmitted through the seed. Storage of seed before sowing reduces the level of fungus in new pastures. Perennial ryegrass cultivars infected with the endophyte fungus are more resistant to drought and attack by pasture pests. Older pastures generally cause more problems than new pastures. The problem occurs in years when there is summer or early autumn rainfall which stimulates the ryegrass plants to shoot. If a dry period of several weeks then stresses the new growth, the production of lolitrem B increases. Sheep show nervous signs when disturbed, but recover if left alone. There is some concern that the fertility and lactation of ewes, and the survival of lambs, may be adversely affected on ryegrass pastures infected with endophyte. Clover growth is also reduced in pastures with ryegrass infected with endophyte.

This is a liver disorder caused by a toxin associated with the growth of the fungus Phomopsis on the dead stems of lupins, usually after summer rains. Sheep show great fluctuations in feed intake from day to day. The disorder may be complicated by simultaneous selenium deficiency.

The cause of this disorder in sheep is the content of pyrrolizidine alkaloids in heliotrope (Heliotr opium europaeum), which occurs in native pastures in the Riverina district of New South Wales, the Murray Valley area of Victoria, and in parts of South Australia. Paterson's curse or salvation Jane (Echium plantagineum) also contains these alkaloids and may be a cause of the disorder in South Australia. The alkaloids, heliotrine and lasiocarpine, cause chronic liver damage over a long period. Copper becomes concentrated in the much smaller number of cells in the necrotic liver. If this copper is suddenly discharged from the liver, the resulting haemolytic crisis (evidenced by the jaundice) causes the death of the animal. Mustering, driving and handling can precipitate the crisis.
Most animals survive at least one summer's grazing on heliotrope. The only way to prevent the disorder is to prevent stock from grazing heliotrope.

Most cases occur in lambs through infection of wounds sustained at marking. Infected animals become lame in one or more limbs; a high proportion of animals may become infected. Most recover without treatment, but some may remain permanently crippled. Good hygiene at lamb-marking is the basis of prevention.

Clostridia are spore-forming anaerobic organisms normally found in soil, particularly soils with a high content of organic matter. It is therefore impossible to eliminate them from the environment. Although losses of stock due to clostridial infections can now be largely prevented by vaccination, it is still worth while preventing gross contamination of the environment. This can occur most readily from decomposing carcasses. Clostridia are normal inhabitants of the gastro-intestinal tract; they multiply rapidly during decomposition and release spores into the environment. Black disease in sheep or cattle is the result of infection of the liver following injury to that organ by immature liver flukes; both the organism and the fluke infestation must be present.

Blackleg is an acute muscular infection to which cattle are more susceptible than sheep. The most susceptible animals are between six months and two years of age and in very good body condition. The disease in sheep is usually the result of infection of wounds, usually those sustained at shearing, crutching, or marking.

Botulism is a disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by Cl. botulinum. The toxin accumulates wherever the organism finds conditions suitable for its proliferation. Grazing livestock may be affected after eating carrion, in which the organism grows rapidly. Drinking-water may become toxic if contaminated by carrion. Damaged feedstuffs and vegetation have been major causes of outbreaks of botulism.

Enterotoxaemia, or pulpy kidney, is an acute fatal disease of sheep caused by the absorption of a toxin produced by the organism CL perfringens type D in the small intestine when conditions there are favourable for its growth. Lambs up to the age of 16 weeks are most frequently affected, although heavy losses sometimes occur in adult sheep. Losses often occur in flocks on high-quality improved pasture or grazing forage crops. Animals in good condition are particularly susceptible. The risk in young lambs is greatest when ewes have an abundant supply of milk. Since it is difficult to predict exactly when feed conditions are most favourable for development of the disease, vaccination is necessary, particularly in districts where pasture conditions favour a regular seasonal incidence.

Tetanus occurs relatively commonly in lambs and less commonly in adult sheep and cattle. The disease is caused by a toxin produced by Cl tetani when it multiplies in a local wound, usually one received at marking, shearing or crutching.

This disease is an important cause of calf mortality in the early weeks of life. The organism responsible is Escherichia coli, of which there are many strains, some of which can cause a severe enteritis and death. It is now known that variations in the virulence of different strains of E. coli reflect varied capacities to produce enterotoxins and other virulence determinants. Vaccines directed against such determinants are now becoming available. Hygiene and feeding are important. Changes in environment, either of the cow in late pregnancy or the calf, may mean exposure to different strains of E. coli. The colostrum may not contain antibodies to these strains.

Sheep of all ages may be infected, but the incidence tends to be higher in young animals, since older animals may have obtained immunity, for the time being, from a previous infection. Immunity lasts from a few months to more than a year. Several organisms have been isolated from affected animals: rickettsia, mycoplasma and bacteria. The relative importance of each agent still has to be determined.

A large proportion of the flock is usually affected. Most cases recover spontaneously within 14 days. Treatment is time-consuming and, even in the worstaffected cases, the blindness or near-blindness which occurs as a result of ulceration of the cornea is temporary.

Contagious ophthalmia of cattle is caused by Moraxella bovis. It is probably the most widespread disease of cattle in northern regions, particularly in the Northern Territory and coastal areas of Queensland. The infection is a more acute type than pink eye in sheep. It may disappear spontaneously within a few weeks, but blindness is a common sequel in severely infected cases.

Contagious foot rot in sheep is endemic in temperate climates and high-rainfall areas in all States. It is also endemic on irrigated pastures. The infection is always present in endemic areas; chronically affected animals can carry the disease for several years. It spreads in wet seasons, when it can survive on the soil and pasture for a few days and be transmitted to the feet of healthy animals. It can be brought on to a property in purchased sheep which are infected but show no lesions or lameness. The infection may be picked up in railway yards, transport vehicles or on stock routes. There are virulent, intermediate, and benign forms of footrot.

All sheep brought on to a property should be isolated until after the first wet season before joining the main flock. When infection occurs, the first aim must be to prevent its spread through the flock. Affected animals should be isolated and treated; contaminated paddocks and yards should be kept free of sheep for 14 days. Treatment may involve various combinations of vaccination, foot-bathing and hoof-paring; chronically infected sheep should be culled.
Scald, clover burn and foot abscess may be confused with foot rot.

Foot abscess is endemic in most sheep-raising areas, but is most prevalent in areas of high rainfall, lush pastures and soils which tend to become boggy when very wet. Under these conditions (eg northern Tasmania in winter) the feet become overgrown and caked with mud. In contrast to foot rot, which affects sheep of all 'ages, foot abscess occurs mainly in older sheep, particularly older ewes in late pregnancy. The disease is difficult to prevent. Routine paring of the feet of older sheep may reduce their susceptibility to infection.

This disease is analagous to foot abscess in sheep, and should probably be referred to as foot abscess. It occurs mainly in areas of high rainfall; any conditions which favour foot bruising or injury, eg stony ground, will also favour development of the disease, particularly in winter.

As the name indicates, this disease is an inflammation of the mammary glands. It remains a major cause of production loss in the dairying industry, in spite of a great deal of research into all its aspects. Some organisms causing the disease, such as Streptococcus agalactiae, infect only the udder and can therefore be controlled more easily than many others which are more widely distributed and attack other body tissues. Streptococcal infection is susceptible to penicillin treatment, but the use of this antibiotic has led to an increase in the incidence of staphylococcal infection, which is more difficult to treat with antibiotics. Staphylococci may be present in parts of the tissue less easily reached by antibiotics introduced into the udder via the teat canals, whereas streptococci are mainly present in the ducts and sinuses. Probably more importantly, staphylococci causing mastitis have built up a substantial resistance to penicillin.

Prevention of mastitis mainly involves meticulous attention to all aspects of milking-shed hygiene and care of equipment such as liners and cups, together with teat-dipping and other measures to reduce the spread of infection, including drycow therapy. Chronically infected cows should be culled.

This is an inflammatory condition of the prepuce, primarily occurring in wethers. In severe cases, the inflammation may extend to the penis (balanitis). Affected animals lose body condition and are susceptible to blowfly strike. Merinos are more susceptible than British breeds.

The causative organism develops only in areas continually wetted with urine rich in urea. Wethers have incomplete development of the penis and prepuce and tend, as a result, to urinate in the sheath. Since the organism can only develop in an environment with a high urea concentration, the disorder occurs predominantly on pastures with a high nitrogen content, particularly leguminous pastures.

Although rough dry vegetation and grass or thistle seeds may cause abrasions on the muzzle and facilitate entry of the virus, the disease is certainly not confined to such pastures. Affected animals develop immunity to further infection. The problems of vaccination are discussed on p 532.

The fungus invades the superficial layers of the skin, which become inflamed and exude a fluid. This is absorbed into the fleece, the fibres of which become bound together into a dense hard mass. The disease is most common in years with a high winter and spring rainfall, affects young sheep particularly, and is infectious. The lesions caused by the fungus heal without treatment. Severely affected sheep may require antibiotic therapy for the lesions to heal to enable shearing.

Babesiosis is an infectious disease of cattle, caused in Australia by Babesia bigemina and Babesia argentina which are transmitted from one animal to another by the cattle tick, Boophilus microplus. It is endemic to regions in northern Australia with annual rainfall exceeding 500 mm, so that it extends through south-eastern Queensland into the north-eastern corner of New South Wales. The infectious agent in some outbreaks may be Anaplasma marginale.

Cattle which have recovered from an infection are temporarily immune. In areas where the cattle tick is endemic and always plentiful, immunity becomes permanent through continuous re-infection. Cattle from tick-free areas are very susceptible, and cattle from areas where the tick population fluctuates widely over long periods suffer periodic loss of immunity and periodic outbreaks of the disease.

Babesiosis may therefore occur (a) when cattle from tick-free areas are taken into or through tick-infested areas, (b) where ticks are present in widely fluctuating numbers, either because of climate or a dipping program, (c) when cattle are taken from a lightly infested area to one heavily infested, (d) after tick-infested cattle have travelled through a clean or lightly infested property, and (e) in calves born at the beginning of a long dry season, and first exposed to ticks at the end of that season. In some of these circumstances, protective vaccination is practised.

Deaths of cattle, loss of body condition in those which recover, reduced milk production in affected dairy cattle and condemnation of carcasses at abattoirs are responsible for serious economic loss to the cattle industry.

The most important nematodes affecting sheep and cattle are listed below. It is not unlikely that chronic nematode infestation, the symptoms of which express themselves largely as unthriftiness of the animal, has a greater total effect on the productivity of the national sheep flock than acute infestations. Its effects are seen as reduced growth-rates in young animals and reduced wool production.
body_text.section: Parasitic nematodes in sheep and cattle

body_text.text: It is thus not surprising that much parasitological research has been directed towards the evolution of strategic drenching programs designed to prevent seasonal upsurges in parasite numbers and to maintain infestations at low levels. The development of broad-spectrum drenches has assisted development of these programs. The 'Wormkiir program for summer-rainfall areas is directed largely at control of barber's pole, black scour and nodule worms. The timing of each drench is calculated to forestall the warm-season rises in numbers of barber's pole worms and to reduce the winter increases in black scour and nodule worms.
body_text.section: Species affected Common Name Scientific Name

body_text.text: In south-eastern Australia the drenching times which will usually form the basis of a strategic program will be December and February (all sheep), pre-lambing (ewes) and at weaning (lambs). Summer drenching ensures that pastures will be as clean as possible when the autumn break occurs. The ewe is usually a more important source of infection of the lamb than pasture contamination; pre-lambing drenching and removal to a pasture as free as possible from contamination is therefore recommended. Lambs suffer an unavoidable stress at weaning; drenching removes the additional, avoidable stress of nematode infection. Weaned lambs should not be put back on the lambing paddock.
body_text.section: Species affected Common Name Scientific Name

body_text.text: Blowfly strike in sheep is a major cause of economic loss in the industry.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Primary strike is mainly caused by the coppery green fly, Lucilia cuprina. It is found in varying numbers all year round but is most prevalent in spring and autumn. Eggs are laid in a moist part of the fleece. The larvae eat the skin and may also attack underlying tissues.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies
