body_text.text: Secondary strike occurs when the larvae of secondary fly species burrow deeply into the tissues exposed by primary strike (expelling the remaining primary strike larvae) and cause a severe inflammatory reaction and a general systemic toxaemia, which may lead to the death of the animal. In less severe cases the animal may develop a temporary fever, with loss of body-weight and tenderness or a break in the whole fleece.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Losses of 20 to 30 per cent, and up to 50 per cent, of the flock have occurred in years of abnormally high rainfall in the pastoral zone.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Breech strike is the most common. Wetting of wool with urine and contamination with faeces are the most common predisposing causes. Degree of skin wrinkle, tail length, size of the area of bare skin surrounding the anus and vulva, distortion of the vulva (so that urine is deflected on to the skin area) and scouring are the main factors which influence individual susceptibility to breech strike.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Body strike usually follows prolonged wetting of the fleece by rain and is often associated with fleece rot, which may occur under these conditions. Mycotic dermatitis is also a predisposing cause. Other factors such as the 'wettability' and the smell of the fleece may also be important.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Pizzle strike is usually associated with continual wetting of belly wool by urine or wet long grass. Sheath rot (posthitis) can be a predisposing cause. Poll strike is most common in horned rams. Flies are attracted by moisture and skin secretions at the base of the horns and by wounds caused by fighting. Wound strike can occur following lamb-marking or shearing.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: The Mules operation is the most effective method of reducing or preventing breech strike. Mulesing has the effect of stretching out skin wrinkles and increasing the area of bare skin around the tail. Done correctly, it has other advantages. It makes crutching and shearing easier, it reduces the incidence of sunburn on the tail and reduces the incidence of anal and/or vulval cancer in ewes.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Crutching is also an effective method of reducing the incidence of breech strike. In wethers and rams crutching is commonly combined with removal of wool from around the pizzle ('ringing') to reduce susceptibility to pizzle strike.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Pizzle dropping and pizzle mulesing have been developed to reduce the incidence of urine contamination of belly wool and hence pizzle strike in wethers. The former involves surgical severance of the tissues between the belly and the sheath enclosing the penis, so that the pizzle hangs below the belly wool. The latter is not favoured because of the danger of rupturing the abdominal wall.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Jetting is a procedure in which insecticide is injected into the fleece at high pressure. The fleece must be wetted to the skin for maximum protection.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Genetic selection can eliminate skin wrinkles or reduce the incidence of wrinkles in the flock. Merinos, particularly the strong-wool strains, are more susceptible to fleece rot and body strike than other breeds but there are resistant animals in all strains. Selection towards greater resistance is therefore possible.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Management can reduce the predisposition to strike. Grazing management and effective control of internal parasites can reduce the incidence of scouring; the timing of shearing can be adjusted so that sheep are in short wool at times of greatest risk.
body_text.section: External parasites (arthropods) of sheep and cattle Blowflies

body_text.text: Keds are wingless parasitic flies about 6 mm long, with stout reddish-brown bodies. They feed entirely on blood and so their excreta stain the wool and further reduce the value of a fleece already damaged through irritation. Keds move rapidly over all areas of the body -often on the surface of the wool -but greatest numbers are found on the neck and shoulders. They are more likely to move from sheep to sheep than lice, especially at shearing. Live keds may leave a shorn fleece and infect another sheep but normally few survive more than four to five days off the animal, as they rapidly weaken and die without access to frequent meals of blood. Keds are more common in colder wetter areas where their numbers increase in autumn and winter and decline in summer. There is a tendency for lice to be less significant in regions where keds are a problem.

This fly is found in an area of northern and north-eastern Australia very similar to that inhabited by the cattle tick. It rarely leaves the animal, except to lay eggs in freshly excreted faeces, and then only for a few seconds. It survives only when cattle (or buffaloes) are present, since a feed of blood is essential for maturity of its eggs. The bite is painful and heavy infestations cause intense irritation which prevents normal feeding and resting, so that animals lose condition or fail to grow at expected rates.

The survival and activity of adult flies is markedly dependent on moisture and temperature. They disappear with the onset of cold weather, and survive best in areas of high humidity, eg along watercourses. Egg development and larval survival in faeces are retarded or reduced by cold and desiccation.
British breeds are more affected than breeds such as the Zebu and its crosses, and show greater skin damage when flies are abundant.
Control by trapping the flies and by spraying or dipping stock is successful to varying degrees. Biological control through the agency of dung beetles is a possible long-term solution.

All lice have the same general life history. They are obligatory parasites; most die within a few days after removal from their host. Some, such as the body louse and foot louse of sheep, are very small (2 mm or less in length) and difficult to see and identify without the aid of good light and a hand lens. Some feed on epithelial debris and some are bloodsucking parasites. Their feeding irritates the animal, and the resultant rubbing and scratching results in damage to the fleece or skin. Affected animals lose condition.

Lice Mature, fully engorged females fall to the ground from the animal and lay their eggs among plant debris. The larvae, or seed ticks, climb up grass stems, posts etc, and attach themselves to passing animals. In the absence of animals they can survive for three to six months, depending on climate. The remainder of the life cycle, through nymphal stages to mature engorged female, is spent on the animal.

Apart from their role as the transmitter of babesiosis (see p 544), the ticks cause severe economic loss to the cattle industry in northern Australia, as a result of their direct effects on the animal. Irritation causes reduction in rates of weight gain and in milk production. The effects of anaemia may be severe, particularly in calves. A large proportion of hides from tick-affected areas are not marketable.

The most important is the itch mite of sheep (Psorergates ovis). Adult mites wander on the skin surface while immature mites burrow deep into the skin. The actual damage is not great but, when animals are sensitised, even small numbers of mites cause irritation and symptoms. The sheep usually bite rather than rub, causing parts of the flanks that can be reached, ie that part below a line drawn from elbow to hip, to have bleached and tangled fleece with a characteristic dry tip. Unlike that due to lice and keds, the irritation commonly increases immediately after shearing. Transmission is most likely when sheep are mustered into yards.

Because only small numbers of mites are needed to affect sensitised animals and because a microscope is needed to see them, only a trained person can detect mites after thorough scraping and testing of the skin and wool of several animals. Where itch mite is suspected, advice should be sought from a stock inspector or veterinarian. Itch mite has been reported in all sheep-growing areas of Australia, but it would seem to be highly significant only in New South Wales and Tasmania where individual flocks may suffer up to 30 per cent loss of wool production unless control measures are adopted.

All States have regulations for the control of lice and keds in sheep. These involve reporting of infestations, quarantine of properties, and treatment of infested sheep. In certain areas all sheep must be dipped yearly after shearing, whether parasites are detected or not. Sheep producers should contact their Department of Agriculture or Primary Industries to determine their local obligations and to obtain detailed information on approved dipping techniques and back-line treatments.
There are now more than 80 products available in Australia for use in sheep dips. Table 1 shows the effectiveness of common products in each category.

In some areas the transient relief from fly strike may influence the choice of a product effective against both lice and blowflies; on other occasions a cheaper dip with activity only against lice may meet the requirements and be economically preferable.

(1) All instructions given by the manufacturer are vitally important to the effective operation of the dip. Special note should be made of replenishment instructions, as dips subject to 'stripping' must be replenished during the operation. Cleanliness of the dip before commencement is essential to prevent bacteria causing severe or fatal infections in the dipped sheep.
(2) Delay dipping until shearing wounds have healed (10 days).

(3) Dip all sheep (and lambs) at the same time, unless adequate arrangements can be made to keep the dipped and the undipped animals separate. A full muster is essential. One infested straggler will, in time, lead to the re-infestation of the whole flock. (4) Avoid dipping in cold or wet weather, and finish the work early in the day to allow the sheep to dry. (5) Keep the sheep in the swim bath for a full half-minute. Often they get through in 10 to 15 seconds and the fleece is not thoroughly soaked. Avoid sudden plunging and push gently backwards to open wool. (6) Do not dip thirsty sheep. Let them cool off and settle down in the yards before beginning operations. (7) Do not shed sheep after dipping, or drive them hard, because 'sweating' greatly increases the tendency to scalding of the skin by some products. Long wool (over three months) promotes scalding. (8) Empty the dipping bath and clean it after use with a disinfectant.
Goats are susceptible to the same range of diseases as sheep, and methods of treatment and prevention are generally similar. Only the main disease problems are briefly discussed here.

Pregnancy toxaemia (see p 538) is caused by stress and particularly by inadequate nutrition during the last few weeks of pregnancy. During this period does should be well fed, should not be subjected to prolonged handling, yarding or shedding without feed, and should have shelter from cold, wet windy weather.

The main clostridial diseases, enterotoxaemia and tetanus, are best controlled by a routine vaccination program. Pregnant does should be vaccinated approximately two weeks before kidding, and kids should be vaccinated at about three weeks of age, again about four weeks later, and then annually for as long as they are maintained. The recommended vaccine dose for goats is 5 mL, compared with 2 mL for sheep. The use of combined vaccines which give additional protection against other less common clostridial diseases should be considered, particularly for valuable stud animals.

Goats are prone to lice infestation, and should be dipped at least annually in the same manner and using the same dipping compounds as are used for sheep. Although their use is not officially approved, many producers are finding that the 'spot-on' preparations formulated for treating cattle lice are effective and more convenient than conventional dipping. Two thorough applications of malathion powder spaced about three weeks apart provide another convenient method of lice control for small numbers of goats. Goats are not susceptible to blowfly strike, except very occasionally in the breech area in association with prolonged scouring. Internal parasites (roundworm, tapeworm and liver fluke) can be controlled, as in sheep, by drenching. Tapeworms are rarely a problem except, occasionally, in young kids, and liver flukes occur only in wet swampy areas. Roundworms, on the other hand, are widespread. Heavy infestations can seriously affect the health and productivity of goats of all ages and can be fatal, particularly in young animals. The frequency of drenching needed for worm control varies with rainfall and stocking rate, and a continual watch should be kept for signs of anaemia, scouring or loss of body and coat condition. Regular drenching every six to eight weeks throughout the year may be necessary for goats heavily stocked in high-rainfall areas.

Foot abscess and foot rot are potential problems in wetter areas, and should be treated in the same manner as in sheep. Regular foot trimming is necessary in most areas to prevent feet from becoming overgrown.
Mastitis and milk fever may occur in all breeds of goats, but are most common in dairy animals. Treatment is the same as for dairy cows.

The following is a brief account of the more common diseases which are associated with economic loss. The main features of the disease are listed, together with appropriate control and preventative methods which can be used to minimise losses. It cannot be too strongly emphasised that an accurate diagnosis of the cause of death or illness in pigs on a farm usually requires a thorough examination of dead and surviving pigs, an appreciation of the history and management of the herd and an adequate collection and submission of specimens to a veterinary laboratory.

Disease of piglets caused by a restriction in their food intake in the first week of life. Can be due to a failure of the sow's milk-supply or a failure of the piglets to suck. Gluconeogenesis does not develop in piglets until approximately the seventh day of life and thus during the first week after birth the piglet's glycogen stores are rapidly exhausted if the intake of milk is restricted. Affected piglets have an unsteady gait, shiver continuously, feel cold to the touch and appear pale. Most affected piglets die if left untreated.
body_text.section: Nutritional diseases in pigs Hypoglycaemia (baby pig disease)

body_text.text: Piglets should be closely observed during the first week of life. Those from a sow whose milk supply has apparently ceased should be provided with a foster mother or with an artificial diet. Protection from cold is most important and piglets should be housed in an environmental temperature of 27 to 30° C.
body_text.section: Nutritional diseases in pigs Hypoglycaemia (baby pig disease)

body_text.text: Is caused by iron deficiency which occurs in piglets confined to pens with concrete floors, and where the sole diet is sow's milk. Affected pigs have a depressed growthrate, particularly after they reach three to four weeks of age. The skin and mucous membranes are pale. Additionally the pigs show respiratory difficulty, lethargy and, in many cases, diarrhoea. Death of affected animals often occurs suddenly, with other pigs surviving in a thin, unthrifty condition.

Iron deficiency can be controlled by the use of iron compounds given either orally or by intramuscular injection. The disease can be prevented either by the administration of iron to each piglet in the first 24 hours of life or by the provision of clean soil.

Two disease entities, the more common mulberry-heart disease and the less common hepatosis dietetica, are associated with deficiencies of vitamin E and selenium. The two diseases occur in rapidly growing pigs in the post-weaning period, most commonly in pigs approximately three months of age. Caused by feeding a high-energy diet low in vitamin E and selenium. In mulberry-heart disease pigs are commonly found dead without previously showing abnormal signs. Some pigs show severe respiratory distress, cyanosis and ataxia. In hepatosis dietetica most pigs are simply found dead.

All clinically affected pigs and all pigs at risk on the property require individual administration of vitamin E and selenium. The control and prevention of both diseases can be effected by inclusion of selenium and vitamin E in the feed.

Zinc deficiency can occur in pigs either because the diet has a low content of zinc or because excess calcium in the diet interferes with absorption of dietary zinc from the gut. The disease is mainly seen in the post-weaning period and causes a depressed appetite, reduced growth-rate and the occurrence of skin lesions, mainly a thickening and cracking of the skin. Control is effected by adding zinc sulfate to or by eliminating any excess of calcium from the diet.

Can occur in pigs having access to food containing excess salt but only if drinking water is not available. Affected animals may die suddenly or may, for three to four days, show muscle tremors, followed by convulsions and death. Affected pigs need to be provided immediately with adequate drinking water.
Smothering of piglets overlain by the sow is more common in litters from heavier sows. Well-designed farrowing stalls will help to prevent losses.
body_text.section: Diseases of pigs caused by mismanagement

body_text.text: Piglets are very susceptible to chilling, deaths occurring as early as two hours after birth. The temperature in the farrowing house should be stable and in the range 27 to 30° C.
body_text.section: Diseases of pigs caused by mismanagement

body_text.text: Heat stroke is caused by driving or handling pigs in very hot weather, by overcrowding, or by failing to provide adequate ventilation or adequate shade and water, particularly during periods of hot weather. It is therefore largely preventable. Affected pigs should be sprayed with cool water immediately, to reduce body temperature.
body_text.section: Diseases of pigs caused by mismanagement

body_text.text: Caused by Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae. Young pigs three to 10 weeks of age are most commonly affected, with economic losses due in the main to a decreased growth-rate and runting. Coughing is also a common manifestation. The severity of the disease varies greatly and is especially influenced by the standard of husbandry. If infected pigs are subjected to cold, draughts, inadequate nutrition or overcrowding the signs of enzootic pneumonia are exacerbated. On the other hand, in well-housed and well-fed pigs the effects of the disease are often negligible. Migrating parasitic larvae (eg Ascaris suum) wandering in the lung tissues are an important predisposing factor.

Treatment consists primarily of providing well-ventilated housing and improved nutrition. Antibiotic therapy is useful in controlling secondary bacteria which frequently invade lungs already damaged by Mycoplasma. The disease can be controlled by taking particular care with housing, feeding and hygiene. It can be eradicated (expensively) by depopulating the piggery completely and repopulating with pneumonia-free HYPAR stock.

An infectious disease, caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae (a bacterium commonly located in piggeries), which causes severe economic loss due to death of pigs and condemnation of carcasses due to arthritis. Contamination of the soil and environment with the causative bacterium occurs through the faeces of affected and carrier pigs. The organism is relatively resistant to sunlight and other environmental influences and is not readily eliminated by disinfectants.

Erysipelas can cause signs varying from sudden death to a long-standing form involving the joints or heart valves. In the acute form, which can be seen in pigs of all ages, the animal ceases to feed, usually vomits and develops a reddish-purple discolouration of the skin. Some pigs develop the characteristic diamond-shaped red patches on the skin. In chronic erysipelas the organism localises in the joints or heart valves.
Affected pigs can be treated with penicillin. Properties on which cases occur should commence, and maintain, a vaccination program.

Thought to be caused by staphylococci, but environmental stress predisposes piglets to the disease. Most cases occur in pigs under five to six weeks of age, with piglets less than one week of age most susceptible. Their skin becomes red and wrinkled and covered with a greasy, greyish exudate. They become dehydrated and weak and frequently die some 24 to 48 hours after first becoming ill.

Antibiotic therapy (applied to the skin and by injection) gives results in affected animals provided the treatment is commenced early. The pens of affected litters need to be cleaned and disinfected before being used by another farrowing sow.

This disease occurs infrequently but losses are substantial on properties involved. Caused by a bacterium, Haemophilus suis. Usually involves pigs two to four months of age which have been recently chilled, trucked or moved to different premises. Onset of the disease is sudden and the mortality rate is high. Affected pigs show rapid shallow breathing and have swollen joints.

Antibiotics are effective in reducing losses provided they are administered early. To assist in prevention it is important to avoid exposing pigs to adverse environmental conditions, especially at weaning.

Caused by several species of Leptospira, most commonly L. pomona and L. hyos (tarassovi) . These bacteria cause abortion in sows and birth of weak piglets, which die shortly after birth. An 'abortion storm' may occur when the disease first appears in a herd, most abortions occurring two to four weeks before the expected birth date of the litter. The source of infection is usually a chronically infected animal which contaminates drinking water or feed either by infected urine or uterine discharge. Urine is a common source of contamination since carrier pigs can excrete leptospirae in their urine for months after last showing any clinical signs.
In treating pigs with leptospirosis, streptomycin is the drug of choice. Control of the disease involves the detection and elimination of carrier pigs and the vaccination of susceptible animals.

Caused by Escherichia coli and most common in piglets two to ten days of age. Piglets which do not obtain colostrum from the sow within a few hours of birth are very susceptible. There are two forms of the disease. The first is a septicaemia which results from the bacteria invading the bloodstream and tissues of the piglet. This mostly occurs in piglets 24 to 48 hours of age, most affected piglets being found dead without showing previous signs. The second form, baby-pig diarrhoea, occurs especially in pigs around three days of age. Affected pigs have a watery yellowish diarrhoea; they rapidly become dehydrated and commonly die within 24 hours.

Management factors play an important role in preventing this disease. Piglets must be provided with a warm, dry environment. The area in which they are being raised must be kept clean, since a buildup of faeces causes a corresponding increase in the numbers of bacteria.

Caused by absorption of toxin produced by Escherichia coli in the pig's intestinal tract. Often occurs in pigs eight to 14 weeks of age, particularly soon after weaning. Changes in feed and housing predispose pigs to oedema disease. Affected pigs cease feeding, are weak, seem to wander aimlessly, and usually show nervous signs such as muscle tremors and convulsions. The pigs affected are often those in the best condition. The course of the disease is short, with death or improvement occurring within 12 to 48 hours.

To minimise losses, pigs should be kept on the same creep feed for at least two weeks after weaning and all changes in feed should be made gradually over a four-to five-day period. On some farms the incorporation of an antibiotic into the feed during the risk period has reduced losses.

An infectious disease which has a wide variety of signs from rapid death (septicaemia) to chronic lameness, pneumonia and diarrhoea (necrotic enteritis). The highest incidence occurs in weaner pigs. In acute salmonellosis a reddish-purple discolouration of the skin is pronounced, especially involving the ears, abdomen and inside the thighs. Affected pigs commonly also show nervous signs such as convulsions; the mortality rate is usually very high. In adult pigs salmonellosis is often expressed as an acute enteritis with a watery diarrhoea, often containing flecks of blood and intestinal lining. A common syndrome in adult pigs which survive the acute enteritis is necrotic enteritis, a chronic thickening of the wall of the caecum and colon. These pigs become important sources of environmental contamination by salmonellae.

Treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics is effective in minimising deaths from acute salmonellosis, but this therapy does entail a risk of producing carrier animals. Treatment of necrotic enteritis is invariably unrewarding. Maintenance of a closed herd, avoidance of stress, disinfection of premises, provision of adequate housing, nutrition and an uncontaminated water supply are each important factors in the prevention of salmonellosis. The prophylactic use of antibiotics in the feed is not recommended because of the risk of developing resistant strains.

Caused by Bruceila suis. In the sow the organism mainly involves the genital tract, causing infertility, birth of small litters, birth of litters which die a few hours after birth, and abortion. In boars, infertility follows an inflammatory reaction in the testicles, with lameness and posterior paralysis often following when the organism localises in the joints and vertebral column. Bruceila suis is an important zoonosis and public health hazard. Control of the disease on affected properties is by testing, followed by disposal of known infected animals.

A prevalent disease which can cause extensive mortality in weaner pigs and which is also associated with decreased production efficiency. Caused by a spirochaete, Treponema hyodysenteriae. This organism is shed in the faeces of affected pigs and (more importantly) by asymptomatic carriers. Thus the disease is often introduced on to a property by recently purchased pigs. Affected pigs show fever and depression and produce characteristic faeces of porridge-like consistency, containing flecks of blood and lining of the intestines. The pigs become progressively dehydrated and, if untreated, die a week or two after the initial onset of diarrhoea.

The disease responds well to treatment, which involves the administration of organic arsenicals or antibiotics to all pigs. Control and prevention involves the prophylactic use of antibiotics in the feed, minimising environmental stress and avoiding the introduction of pigs from an outside source, which may shed the organism.

Swine tuberculosis embraces the three tuberculosis entities, caused by Mycobacterium bovis, M. avium and M. intracellulare. M. bovis infection in pigs is now rare. M. avium infection and infection due to the atypical mycobacterium (M. intracellulare) present similar lesions at post-mortem but the origins of these bacteria are different. Birds, in particular free-range poultry, are the most likely sources of infection of pigs with avian tuberculosis. A contaminated environment is usually incriminated in M. intracellulare infections. The disease is usually non-progressive and is restricted to the lymph nodes of the head and neck and to the mesenteric lymph nodes.

Control of swine tuberculosis involves initially the determination of the type of organism causing the condition on the property and then the application of specific measures, such as eliminating contact with poultry.

Ascarids (Ascaris suum) are located, as adults, in the small intestine. They cause poor growth-rates and a lowered resistance to other diseases. Migrating ascarid larvae contribute to the aetiology of enzootic pneumonia.

Adequate drainage, frequent removal of faeces from pens and confinement of pigs to concrete-floored pens assist in the control of ascarids; piperazine salts, levamisole, dichlorvos and other drugs are effective anthelminthics against ascarids.

The stomach worms, Hyostrongylus rubidus, Ascarops and Physocephalus, may cause parasitic gastritis and are occasional causes of poor growth, anaemia and diarrhoea in young pigs. The broad-spectrum anthelminthics used to treat pigs with ascarids are also efficient in removing stomach worms.

Trichuris suis (whipworm) inhabits the caecum and if present in large numbers can cause diarrhoea accompanied by the passage of mucous and blood. Dichlorvos and levamisole are efficient in their removal.
Oesophagostomum species (nodule worm) inhabit the large intestine and can cause loss of condition and diarrhoea. Broad-spectrum anthelminthics are effective in treatment.

Stephanurus dentatus (kidney worm) is important in tropical and subtropical localities. This parasite inhabits the tissues surrounding the kidneys, but the migrating larvae and young wandering adults cause a good deal of damage in other tissues, particularly the liver. The main clinical sign is poor growth. Stiffness and lameness of the hind legs are also frequently seen. Levamisole is effective in removing adult kidney worms. Control depends largely on ensuring that eggs passed in the urine of infected pigs are exposed to sunlight and drying, and on denying access to any area (wallow etc) which may be contaminated with urine.

Sarcoptic mange is caused by a mite, Sarcoptes scabei. Pigs in poor condition appear to be more susceptible and it is common to find sarcoptic mange in a piggery in which overcrowding, poor nutrition and general mismanagement are prevalent.

The female mite burrows into the horny layer of the pig's skin, forming galleries in which the eggs are laid. The hatched immature larvae may develop in these galleries or may migrate over the skin surface. The life cycle, from egg to egg-laying female, usually takes 14 to 17 days. Direct contact with infested animals is the most important method of spread; only in cooler months may infested bedding be a source of infestation. Temperature is the main factor affecting survival of the mite away from the pig. In winter the mites may survive on inert material for up to three days, but at temperatures above 30° C they survive for only an hour if separated from their host.

There is a general reddening of the skin and the affected areas are intensely itchy, which results in persistent scratching and rubbing by the animal. Loss of hair and thickening and wrinkling of the skin follows. The effects on growth-rate and feed conversion are highly significant.

An effective control program should be aimed at either reducing the level of infestation in sows and boars or eradicating the mites entirely from the sow at the point of farrowing. This can be achieved by three thorough sprays, 10 days apart, using an acaricide such as diazinon. All parts of the skin (including inside the ears, under the tail and between the legs) must be adequately sprayed.

Diseases due to deficiencies of minerals or vitamins are now much less common than some years ago. Slipped tendon syndrome is still common, particularly in meat chickens and turkeys. There are several causes: manganese, choline or biotin deficiencies in the diet or excess dietary calcium or phosphorus, which interfere with manganese absorption from the gut. Rickets is failure of calcification, particularly of long bones, and leads to leg weakness. In theory, rickets should not occur, because the classic causes -vitamin D and calcium deficiencies -should be easily counteracted. However, it is still occasionally seen in growing meat chickens, where some unknown cause is acting.

The fatty liver syndrome is a very common disorder of caged layers when near peak production. The cause is unknown but the disease is more common with excess energy intake, when birds are obese. Production is depressed and the bird dies if the liver haemorrhages. Choline chloride treatment usually has little effect.

The fatty liver and kidney syndrome occurs in young birds two to five weeks old in those countries where wheat is used as the basic grain in the diet. Its incidence has been reduced by the addition of biotin to the diet, and it is now infrequently seen in Australia.

Cholera is a widespread febrile disease of turkeys, chickens, ducks and geese, caused by the bacterium Pasteurella multocida. The disease may be acute or chronic. High mortality can occur with the acute form. The chronic form is characterised by swollen wattles and poor production. Rigid quarantine, rigid vermin and wildbird control, and rapid removal of sick or dead birds are essential. Bacterins have a varying efficacy but should be used.
body_text.section: Bacterial diseases in poultry Cholera (fowl cholera)

body_text.text: CRD is caused by a pathogenic mycoplasma, Mycoplasma gallisepticum (MG). There is a widespread clinical incidence in broilers and in continuous-layer operations. Transmission is both ovarian and respiratory. Control is by elimination of the infection from primary breeding stock -by heat-treating the fertile eggs or by dipping eggs in antibiotic solution before setting. Growth, feed conversion and reproductive performance are all adversely affected. The appearance of CRD is influenced by the rate of ovarian transmission and by stress factors. Other diseases, particularly infectious bronchitis and fowl pox, and cold are important stress factors. Preventive medication for broilers (antibiotics in the drinking water) is commonly practised.

Escherichia coli is ubiquitous. Yolk-sac infection, navel infection or omphalitis occur in the first few days of life. E. coli gains entry to the chick through poor hygiene and poor sanitation of eggs and hatchery. Primary coliform infection in growing stock may occur in a highly contaminated, poorly ventilated environment. Secondary colibacillosis is more common -as a sequel of infection with infectious bronchitis or CRD. In laying birds, egg peritonitis and salpingitis are more commonly seen in unhygienic environments.

This widespread respiratory disease is seen mostly during adolescence or in adults. It is rare in broilers but very common in continuous-layer operations. Haemophilus paragallinarum is relatively fragile; transmission is by close contact with carrier birds. The respiratory infection is quite severe, especially when combined with MG infection. Control is by (a) purchasing uninfected stock, (b) maintaining good ventilation without chilling, (c) controlling MG and infectious bronchitis, (d) a high standard of hygiene, including water sanitation, and (e) prophylactic medication, particularly of a winter-reared flock. Acute infection occurs two to three days after clean birds are mixed with infected or recovered birds. It is important to separate age-groups, especially from carriers. New, apparently effective, bacterins are now available.

Most commonly seen in turkeys and quail, but rare in chickens, erysipelas is due to a bacterium. Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae. Prevention is by attention to general hygiene, desnooding turkey males (as day-old poults) and vaccinating where endemic.

Caused by Mycoplasma synoviae. Occurs naturally in chickens and turkeys. May cause a very mild airsaculitis, similar to that caused by MG, as well as inflammation of the synovial membranes of joints, leading to swelling and lameness, and reduced growth-rate and food conversion. Breast blisters are common. Secondary infection of joints and tendon sheaths, usually with Staphylococcus aureus, often occurs. Ovarian transmission is of major importance, as for MG, and some spread is respiratory. Control is by eradication from primary breeders by heat treatment of hatching eggs.

Clostridium perfringens type C is a common minor resident of the intestine. Primary invasion of the gut wall, with damage to the lining (as with coccidiosis), allows entry and multiplication of, and toxin production by, these clostridia. Some litter materials may be heavily contaminated. Its effects are seen as a sudden increase in mortality of chickens two to five weeks old. Mortality may reach 30 per cent but is usually 5 to 15 per cent. Control involves treatment of both the primary cause, eg coccidiosis, and the clostridial infection. Replace litter after thorough disinfection of the environment.

Chlamydia psittaci causes this disease of humans and most bird species. Natural infections in parrots become clinical under stress. Epizootics are common in turkeys in the United States. Fowls are fairly resistant. Commonest in aviary birds, where it occurs as a febrile illness of short duration; mortality is high (greater than 50 per cent) in untreated birds. Recovered birds are carriers. There are legislative provisions in most States; a 45-day treatment with oxytetracycline of all in-contact birds is required.

Salmonella pullorum causes affected chicks to have a 'humped-back' appearance, ruffled feathers and pasted vent; they cheep continuously and mortality is high to very high. Compulsory blood testing of commercial breeding stock has eliminated this previously devastating disease from commercial flocks throughout Australia, but it is still present in some non-commercial flocks. Infected eggs cause rapid transmission within incubators. Treatment is not advised. Legislative provisions require blood tests of breeders; positive birds are slaughtered.

An important public health disease, caused by any serotype of Salmonella apart from S. pullorum or S. gallinarum (not in Australia). S. typhimurium is possibly the most important. The septicaemia or severe enteritis affects young chicks, poults, ducklings or any other young bird. Cold stress is an important 'trigger'. Salmonellae may enter through pores in the shell from adult carriers. Floor eggs, poor egg sanitation and poor incubator sanitation are all important, also contaminated feeds, equipment or water.

This is a febrile illness of chickens, turkeys, ducks and geese of any age. It is rare in commercial flocks. The organism (Borellia anserina) is transmitted by the poultry tick or red mite. A vaccine is available. Remove ticks and mites from the environment; suspend roosts by wire.

Mycobacterium avium causes this chronic wasting disease. It is rarely seen in birds less than 18 months old and is very uncommon in commercial flocks. Spread chiefly by infected faeces; ground where tuberculous birds have been is permanently 'unsuitable' for holding poultry. The organism causes lesions in pigs and, rarely, in humans; it sensitises cattle to the tuberculin test. Control is therefore by removal of birds from infected ground. Tuberculin testing may be required under legislative provisions.

These are ubiquitous in Australian flocks, but are not always associated with clinical disease. They are resistant viruses, transmitted vertically through the egg, and horizontally from bird to bird. Diseases caused are haemorrhagic enteritis in turkeys, splenomegaly in chickens, inclusion body hepatitis, and an egg-drop syndrome caused by the haemagglutinating adenovirus, for which a vaccine has been prepared. Ducks are considered natural carriers of this haemagglutinating adenovirus.

'Epidemic tremor'is caused by an enterovirus of the picornavirus group. It is embryotransmitted and characterised by ataxia and tremor in chicks up to six weeks old. Chickens, turkeys, Japanese quail and pheasants succumb to natural infections. Spread also occurs via faeces. Older birds show no neurologic signs but a sharp decline in egg production is seen in unprotected adults. The disease is of serious economic importance to hatcheries. Prevention is by vaccination of birds at 10 to 14 weeks of age with live vaccine in the drinking water.

Not present in Australia. This Influenza A virus disease of birds can cause up to 100 per cent mortality. Two outbreaks occured in Victoria in the decade between 1976 and 1986. One, in outer metropolitan Melbourne, was eradicated swiftly by slaughter of the infected fowl and duck flocks. The other, at Bendigo, was also eradicated. Influenza viruses occur naturally in wild fowl, especially waterfowl, and it is important to prevent contact of these with domestic poultry flocks.

One-time scourge of the poultry industry, this pox virus is also of importance in turkey and squab raising. Strains of varying virulence abound, also a turkey pox, a pigeon pox and a canary pox virus. The disease may occur as (a) a skin type which is characterised by wart-like growths on the comb and wattles, or (b) a less common diphtheritic form in which white patches occur inside the mouth and mortality is fairly high -in severe cases up to 50 per cent. Pox may occur at any age and is transmitted through the skin by injury or mechanical transfer by mosquitoes. Vaccination is by injecting a live virus into the wing web or feather follicle.

Very common and widespread. A highly contagious, acute respiratory disease due to a coronavirus. A nephrosis may occur in birds up to eight weeks old, particularly during winter months and on diets containing meat and bone meals. The respiratory effect is usually not severe but may predispose to MG infection. Reduced egg production may be the only sign seen in adult layers, but there can be misshapen shells and poor-quality albumen occurring along with the respiratory disease. Livevirus vaccination should be carried out at four days, four weeks and four months via eye drop, nose drop, aerosol spray or drinking-water application.

Highly contagious, almost ubiquitous, viral disease of chickens at two to six weeks old. There is a low mortality with general flock depression; morbidity is close to 100 per cent. The bursa of Fabricius is severely damaged, leading to problems of immuno-suppression, such as gangrenous dermatitis, inclusion body hepatitis and poor response to vaccinations against other diseases. Control is by vaccination of breeding birds; passive antibody protection is imparted to the chicks for a limited time. Live-virus vaccine is given to adult birds in the drinking water.

A herpes virus disease of the chicken, and less commonly of turkeys and pheasants, often seen as a severe respiratory disease with gasping respiration and severe conjunctivitis. It occurs more commonly as a milder respiratory infection with a slight increase in mortality. When severe haemorrhagic tracheitis occurs, mortality may reach 40 to 50 per cent. It is a serious disease of birds of all ages and fairly widespread; epizootics occur from time to time. Legislative provisions exist in some States. Vaccination is with a live mild virus by eye drop, cloacal administration or via the drinking water.
Virus subgroups A and B are known in Australia and are almost ubiquitous amongst chickens. They are transmitted via the ovary and slowly by bird-to-bird contact.

Tumours are produced in a percentage of infected birds and account for a high percentage of deaths of adult birds. Infection significantly reduces egg production, egg quality and size, and hatchability. Economically, lymphoid leukosis is one of the most important diseases of poultry world-wide. Control is by eradication from breeders, which is now technically and commercially feasible.

A herpes virus disease of the chicken only, causing tumour development around 12 to 16 weeks of age but as early as eight weeks. The virus is shed in feather follicle cells and is ubiquitous amongst chickens. Mortality of infected birds may reach 30 per cent up to 24 weeks of age. The virus is highly resistant in the environment and infects chickens in the first days of life. Vaccination is with a live herpes virus from turkeys or an attenuated mild Marek's virus strain given by injection at one day old. This disease is amongst the most economically damaging diseases of the chicken. Immunosuppressive effects can be very severe, particularly with respect to coccidiosis.

Highly infectious and highly contagious respiratory disease of the chicken and turkey. Natural outbreaks are not common in other bird species but many are capable of infection. Waterfowl are fairly resistant; parrots may be natural reservoirs. The paramyxovirus is fairly resistant, and three levels of strain virulence are recognised.
Velogenic. Generally fatal with up to 100 per cent mortality (occurred in Australia in 1932 and 1934).
Moderately pathogenic, with respiratory and nervous signs and up to 30 per cent mortality. Some milder mesogenic strains are used as vaccines.

The disease is not present in Australia. Several avirulent strains of the virus are widespread, such as the V4 Australian strain which is produced as live vaccine. Its use is not permitted in Australia. Humans handling infected birds, or vaccines, can be infected with the virus, but only develop a transient conjunctivitis.
body_text.section: Lentogenic. Producing mild or inapparent disease.

body_text.text: Ubiquitous in Australian flocks. Spread is both ovarian and by bird-to-bird contact. Viral arthritis (tenosynovitis) is the most important reovirus infection in chickens. Poor growth, poor feed-conversion and runting are common manifestations of reovirus infection. There are no known control measures as yet in Australia, but vaccines have been tried overseas.

Natural to turkeys and causing tumour formation. Contamination of vaccines in Australia during the 1970s resulted in serious and widespread disease in chickens, characterised by proventriculitis, runting, abnormal feathering and sometimes quite high mortality. Measures are now taken to ensure that vaccines are not contaminated with this virus.

Aspergillus fumigatus causes 'brooder pneumonia' in young chicks. All bird species are susceptible. The fungus multiplies in decaying organic matter; therefore attention to hygiene, particularly in hatcheries, is a necessary control measure.

Candida albicans causes 'thrush' and 'sour crop' and is usually a problem of individual birds rather than the flock. The fungus grows in moist organic matter; excessive antibiotic usage allows its proliferation. Attention to hygiene is essential.

Mycotoxicosis is of serious concern commercially since the toxin may be present in feed ingredients such as peanut meals and cause very high mortalities. Aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus flavus is the best known. Feed mills constantly check feeds. The mycotoxins are also oncogenic and immunosuppressive in lower doses. Ducklings are the most sensitive species. Improper storage of feed favours fungal growth.

Histomonas meleagridis causes liver damage and an inflammation of the caecum. Turkeys, peafowl and pheasants are particularly susceptible and high mortality can occur. The disease is transmitted by the caecal worm. It is common in the chicken but not as serious as in other species. Controlled by including a histomonastat in the feed, improving hygiene, control of the caecal worm, and not allowing birds access to earthworms.
body_text.section: Protozoan diseases in poultry Blackhead (histomoniasis or enterohepatitis)

body_text.text: Caused by various Eimeria species which are ubiquitous amongst poultry. The disease occurs when the number of sporolated oocysts of Eimeria is beyond the capacity of gut wall defences to handle; this occurs at high stocking densities and with warm moist litter. A severe and bloody enteritis results. Mortality can be very high. Until the advent of modern coccidiostats, regular severe losses occurred. Modern broiler farming exists only by inclusion of coccidiostats in the feed and maintaining a dry litter.

Ascaridia galli is the largest roundworm of poultry; the eggs are very resistant, allowing most poultry flocks to be infested. Very heavy burdens may produce illthrift, anaemia and poor production efficiency. Broilers are rarely infested as they are slaughtered too young for the parasite to establish. Piperazine treatment is effective. The small hair worm Capillaria obsignata occasionally causes enteritis and production losses. Treatment with levamisole is effective. The caecal worm Heterakis gallinarum is not significant in itself, but may transmit blackhead.

Echidnophaga gallinacea, the stickfast flea, attaches itself to the head parts particularly. It may also attach to other animal species, which can thus act as reservoirs of supply of fleas. Although now rare in commercial flocks, it is a serious pest and can kill young birds. Its incidence is notifiable in all States.

Lice commonly infest all species of birds. The body louse Eomenacanthus stramineus is the most common among commercial poultry, and heavy infestations cause production losses. It is very common on continuous-layer farms. All infested birds should be treated twice, with 10 days between treatments.

A number of mites infest poultry; some are bloodsuckers and may transmit tick fever and fowl pox. Production losses may be substantial with heavy infestations. The mite feeds on the bird chiefly at night, hiding under roosts and in other dark places through the day; both the bird and the environment must therefore be treated.
In contrast to lice, ticks can live for a substantial time away from host birds. Argas persicus is a bloodsucker and transmits tick fever.
Cage layer fatigue is characterised by inability of the bird to stand, and by marked bone fragility. Calcium deficiency will predispose, but other factors are also involved.
body_text.section: Other diseases and disorders in poultry

body_text.text: Cannibalism is a natural vice among chickens. Pecking may lead to death due to haemorrhage or disembowelment. Cannibalism is more prevalent under conditions of overcrowding, excess humidity, excessive lighting or shafts of sunlight. Prevention is by controlling these influences; beak trimming may be necessary.
body_text.section: Other diseases and disorders in poultry

body_text.text: Hysteria is only an occasional problem involving the whole flock. The disorder affects birds of any age. Birds become unmanageable and injure themselves. A number of causes can be involved but are often difficult to identify. Control is by decreasing light intensity and reducing stocking density.
body_text.section: Other diseases and disorders in poultry

body_text.text: Tibial dyschondroplasia (focal osteodystrophy) is very common in some meat chickens. A large cartilage plug in the growth plate of long bones causes architectural leg weakness or distortion. The cause is unknown; some breeds are more disposed to the disorder than others.
body_text.section: Other diseases and disorders in poultry

body_text.text: Australia is particularly fortunate in being free from most of the major horse diseases, 'strangles' (caused by Streptococcus equi), influenza, ringworm, mange, tetanus and worm parasites being the main ones present.

Strangles is not a common disease, but is contagious and in a few cases fatal. It is characterised by swelling of the lymph glands under the jaw, watery nasal discharge and rise of temperature. Sulpha drugs and penicillin have made treatment easier. Horses can be immunised. Young horses are the most susceptible.

Worms are a major problem in horses and this fact is not very well appreciated. Strongyles (redworms) can cause considerable unthriftiness and disability; they are difficult to eliminate from country continually stocked with horses. All horses should be drenched from four to 12 times a year; foals should be drenched at three to five months and again at weaning. Paste drenches can be easily administered by the owner. Liquid drenches are given via stomach tube by a veterinarian.
Tetanus is controlled by the use of tetanus antiserum when a horse is wounded. All valuable horses should be immunised by a course of tetanus toxoid injections and regular boosters.

Horses (some more than others) are susceptible to colic (stomach pains) which is due to faulty feeding, watering and work practices; early attention is essential. There are several forms of colic. The affected horse will be noticed biting or kicking at its flank, lying down and rolling, and showing some distress. Usually it will not feed or drink, and does not urinate. A twisted bowel may result in similar symptoms.

Teeth need regular attention, particularly when horses are fed on concentrates. Bad teeth can cause considerable unthriftiness. They should be inspected regularly, and if necessary filed to remove sharp edges and unevenness; sharp teeth often cause bad bitting or mouthing troubles.
Bot flies (Castrophilus spp.) are seldom more than an annoyance to the horse, but can be controlled by drenching annually about May, when the larval stage is present in the stomach.

There are a number of unsoundnesses in horses, some of which are hereditary and can thus pass to the offspring. Atresia coli. A complete lack of development of the intestine in the region of the ascending colon. Big head. The gradual development of enlarged, softened and porous bones in the head. Bleeding. Susceptibility to bursting of blood vessels of the nasal mucosa due to the thinness of the walls. Bog spavin. A distension of the joint oil-bag at the inner and upper part of the joint. It rarely causes lameness unless work is severe, but is an unsightly blemish. Bone spavin. The growing together of the small bones at the inner and lower part of the hock, so that they become a solid mass. Once they have grown firmly together, the defect does not often incapacitate the animal and does not always cause lameness.

back_matter.text: Curb. An enlargement of a ligament at the back of the hock about 10 to 12 cm below the joint; is best observed by standing at the side of the animal. Parrot mouth. A malformation caused by upper jaw overgrowth or shorter lower jaw. Predisposition to heaves. Referred to as 'broken-winded'. The horse breathes with a laboured, double respiratory movement. Work aggravates the condition. Predisposition to laminitis (founder). Occurs mainly in ponies or horses with pony blood. This gene is difficult to eradicate because some horses are managed in such a way that their susceptibility to laminitis is never revealed. Ringbone. A long enlargement of the pasterns anywhere between the fetlock and coronet. The jarring from hard work causes inflammation of the periosteum of faulty or poor-quality bone and a bony growth results. Roaring. The noise made during hard breathing by horses which have one side of their larynx paralysed. The vocal cord becomes loosened and gives rise to the 'whistle' or 'roar'. Roaring can generally be cured by an operation called 'hobdaying'. Side bone. The ossification of the cartilages at the sides of the foot; free movement of the foot is prevented. It is most common in heavy horses. Stringhalt. Takes two forms, one hereditary and one due to eating certain plants. It is a nervous complaint, and consists of a peculiar high hock action which is often snappy or jerky. Thoroughpin. The enlargement of a small synovial capsule situated in the 'web' of the hock. It can be pressed from side to side. Wind-sucking or crib-biting. A habit usually learnt as a result of boredom. Windsuckers are generally poor doers and are not welcome in stables as they teach others the habit. Usually the front teeth are badly worn or rounded.
